PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Prime Minister. I ask: what did Mr Keating mean yesterday when he said that in the last Iraqi conflict with Saddam Hussein `we should have finished him off'? Is this the same Mr Keating who, according to Senator Evans's former leader, Mr Hawke, opposed Australia's involvement by saying—and I quote from the Hawke book—`What has the US done for us?' Does this not now demonstrate not only embarrassing diplomacy but also revisionist history with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight?

—That is a pretty cheap collection of shots from Senator Hill, as one would expect, trying to make squalid political capital out of a very serious international affair that is unfolding at the moment in circumstances that are a matter of concern to us all. Whatever might have been said in the rough and tumble of events back in 1991—and I cannot remember what Mr Keating may have said on that particular issue in the course of the discussions which took place—it bears no resemblance whatsoever, has no relevance whatsoever, to the circumstance as it now exists.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that then, as now, this government acted in support of the gulf coalition because of the way in which it was run not as a unilateral exercise by any country advancing its own national interest but rather as part of a full-scale international effort under the full authority of the United Nations with the full support of the entire international community. It was not a situation then or now that can be characterised as a United States operation, any more than the kind of reaction that is developing in the international community now to the threatened re-escalation of this conflict could be construed as simply a United States response.

There is a clearly a mood to ensure that there is no repetition of the unhappy events of 1990 when Iraq did manage to invade Kuwait, taking the world unawares and its neighbour unawares as it did so. Nobody wants to see a repetition of that. Indeed, in all the circumstances of this situation as it is now unfolding it does appear that the response of the international community has been so swift and so decisive, and the messages given have been so clear, that it is unlikely that the situation will deteriorate further. That should be an occasion for congratulations and enthusiasm by the opposition, not cheap party point scoring of the kind it is trying to engage in now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The cheap political points were clearly on the side of Mr Keating yesterday, who obviously wanted to take benefit from the success of the gulf coalition. But I am surprised that the minister cannot remember what occurred at that time because, according to Bob Hawke, Senator Evans actually contributed to this exchange. When Mr Keating said that he did not want to participate and said, `What has the US done for us?' Bob Hawke said, `I was quick to point out, as was Gareth, that we were acting to back the UN, not the US.'

PARA.TAB: The point is this: has Senator Evans had a word to the Prime Minister about his undiplomatic contribution yesterday and suggested that it is not in Australia's best interests? Perhaps with the benefit of revisionist hindsight, can we expect the Prime Minister to be a little more constructive in this instance than he was on the last occasion?

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not occur to me to have a word with the Prime Minister of the kind that is being suggested to me by Senator Hill, because I have no quarrel at all with what the Prime Minister said yesterday. He responded to the situation as he saw it unfolding with a clear demonstration and a clear statement of the kind of support that could be expected for the international community from Australia should this situation deteriorate to the point where conflict might occur. We all hope that that will not happen. But if it does, and if a UN mandated response is in fact agreed by the international community, Australia could reasonably be expected to be part of that.

PARA.TAB: That was the essence of what Mr Keating was saying yesterday. I certainly have no quarrel with that, and I do not think anyone else in the Australian community would have any quarrel with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. In light of the recent concerns expressed about some aspects of the Uruguay Round results, and with the implementation date of the agreement approaching, what will the successful ratification of the Uruguay Round legislation mean for Australia?

—It does seem that everyone who has a favourite issue anywhere in the world has locked onto the GATT these days and the outcome of the Uruguay Round to typecast it as the source of the particular evil that is their primary concern. Recently we have heard in Australian media and other commentaries suggestions that the Uruguay Round result will do everything from worsening the plight of women in Ethiopia to making Australian labelling of Australian products illegal and preventing the conducting of a `Buy Australian' campaign. All the rumours in the world are being run. They are fundamentally inaccurate, they demonstrate a very poor understanding of what the agreement is all about, and they fail to take into account, for example, what it will mean for jobs for Australians and jobs for people in other countries.

PARA.TAB: The Uruguay Round will result in long-term major boosts to the Australian economy across all sections of industry—mining, agriculture, manufacturing services and jobs for Australians right across the board. In the absence of the Round, we would lose about $5 billion of exports, about $4.4 billion of GDP and the unemployment would be about one per cent higher than it otherwise would be. I do not know why anybody would think that is a good outcome; I do not know why anybody would be advocating that.

If you want to oppose the GATT, you should not come here. You should go down to Leeton and tell the rice growers that they should not get access to the Japanese market. If you do not like GATT, you should go to the meatworks and tell the meatworkers that they should not get the chance to sell their beef on the US market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking to the US Congress? To whom are you talking?

—I am talking to the Deputy President. That is my responsibility and I would always do that, of course. It is very important to make those points clear. There are also concerns about the impact on developing countries. Yet the two industries of greatest importance to developing countries are textiles and agriculture, and they both make significant gains in terms of market access for producers of textiles and agriculture.

PARA.TAB: Let us talk about two of the specifics—first, the wonderful story that it will worsen the plight of Ethiopian women. It should be made clear that Ethiopia is not a member of the GATT and is in no way bound by any of the rules of the GATT.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—It was reported recently in the media. Its major commodity exports already face low and preferential tariffs.

PARA.TAB: Let us put another furphy to rest. There is a story about—it was on the ABC radio here in Canberra, to my great chagrin—that the GATT and the Uruguay Round will in some way stop us labelling Australian products so that we can identify them and that somehow it will stop us running `Buy Australian' campaigns. That is absolutely untrue. There is no way that anything in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will impact upon our capacity to label goods in this way or to promote `Buy Australian' campaigns to our heart's content. So let us not try to undermine the GATT by these sorts of campaigns. The last thing we want to do is to undermine something that could make unemployment one per cent higher than it would otherwise be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Given all of those things, will the delay in the United States congressional vote on the Uruguay Round legislation mean that it could fail to be ratified by the United States? What are the implications of that for Australia?

—This is an important question. Many Australians who are potential beneficiaries are concerned about the delays in the United States' consideration of this matter. In the Jakarta trade ministers meeting last week the deputy United States trade representative made it clear that her view was that the legislation would pass the House on 29 November and the Senate on 1 December and that there would be a comfortable majority. While we would prefer that it not be delayed, we have to note that it is probable that it will pass the United States Congress before it passes the Australian parliament because our timetable will finish slightly later than 1 December.
—Whose fault is that?

—It is nobody's fault. They are both perfectly ample times. I am simply saying that a lot of people are concerned about the timetable. I am trying to put it in context. There is no fault in either case. We greatly support what the Clinton administration has tried to do in getting the legislation through Congress. We hope it will be successful. When the Congress re-convenes after the election it will be the existing Congress and all the indications are that there should be a majority. It is important for Australia that the legislation be passed and for that reason we have been working very hard to build up a consensus of support for it. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to his recent appointments and reappointments to the Immigration Review Tribunal. Firstly, is the minister aware of allegations, supported apparently by affidavit, of corrupt dealings by one of the Victorian reappointees, Mr Joe Italiano, and if so, what action does he propose to take? Secondly, can he explain to the Senate the reasons for appointing to the IRT two preselected Labor Party candidates for the next Victorian state election, Mr Garth Head and Ms Lyn Kosky, and for reappointing an already preselected candidate, Mr Joe Italiano? Thirdly, can he also explain the reasons for reappointing Mr Tony Labbozzetta, a member of the ALP, to the IRT in New South Wales despite his having sat on only four cases in the last four years and having made only one decision in that four-year period?

—I have seen some of this information, some of this scuttlebutt, around the place. I suppose that I, in a sense, have been sickened by it. We have found that there has been the degradation of people's reputations under parliamentary privilege by the other side in the Victorian parliament. Senator Short raised the question of Mr Italiano. I have written to Mr Cooper, the person in the Victorian parliament who raised these allegations under parliamentary privilege, and said to him, `If you have got something, we would like to see it. Please provide it and we will act on it.' I say to Senator Short that I think the matters raised about Mr Italiano were raised some six or seven years ago. They had no legs then; if they have got legs now, then obviously we will have a look at them.

PARA.TAB: It does Senator Short no good to drag up a case and, under the protection which he has but which the person concerned does not have, raise allegations about criminality. If Senator Short has got something, he should put it up or shut up. That is what I have said to Mr Cooper and that is what I say to Senator Short.

In terms of the other people, I have seen in recent days as well that I have been criticised for appointing people with party affiliation. In that context, I have discovered that I have appointed someone with a Liberal Party affiliation to the IRT. I refer to Ms Kosky and Ms Dollis. Those two people were assessed by an assessment panel. Kosky and Dollis were recommended to me for appointment, and it would have been against any—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't ask about Dollis.

—I know that Senator Short did not ask about Dollis but she is a person who has been raised as well. I raise it in the context of the slur that Senator Short is trying to raise about political appointments. They were assessed by the panel, they were very highly recommended and I proceeded with those appointments.

PARA.TAB: Italiano was also recommended for appointment. He was assessed positively and he was also appointed. My point is that a number of people applied for these jobs. The jobs were advertised, a list of people was assessed by a panel, that panel made recommendations to me and, in many of those instances, I accepted their recommendations.

This process has, in my mind, been geared by a number of imperatives: first, to find the best possible people for the job; secondly, to rely on and draw from a diverse group; and, thirdly, to maintain the independence of this particular body.

I say to honourable senators in that context—in relation to appointments to both the IRT and the RRT, the Refugee Review Tribunal—that I have gone out of my way to ensure that the people appointed are independent of any influence from me and from the department. For that reason, we have come up with a very diverse batch of people, both here and in terms of the RRT. In fact, Senator Short at some stage in estimates committees reflected on the appointments to the RRT. The same principles apply. I want to see people in these positions who are not beholden either to me or to the immigration department—and that is what we have here. I am quite happy with the talent of the people appointed.

I refer to a couple of those reflected on by Senator Short—Italiano and Head. My information from the tribunal is that these people, who have been appointed for some time, particularly Italiano, have been performing extremely well. I would rather judge people on their performance and on their promise rather than blackguard them because of some political affiliation that Senator Short would like to draw on in a very unfair way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I cannot thank the minister for his complete non-answer, but I pick up a couple of his points. He said that all the positions filled were advertised. Is it a fact that one of the preselected ALP candidates, Mr Garth Head, was appointed in December 1993—out of the normal term of appointments—and that the position to which he was appointed was not advertised? What were the reasons for that? As there is now a noticeable stench surrounding several of the IRT appointments that Senator Bolkus has made, and the reappointments—and, I might add, the non-reappointment of Victorian principal member Michael Clothier, who has been replaced by a former Labor party staffer without a law degree—will the minister urgently re-examine his complete non-answer yesterday to my questions on notice and come clean that the real reasons for many of his appointments are nothing other than jobs for his Labor mates?

—I am continually stunned by the ignorance and the lack of knowledge that Senator Short brings to this portfolio. Mr Head was appointed last year; vacancies do arise. That appointment was announced at the time and, as vacancies continue to arise, we will appoint people, as we always do. I find a very stark contrast between—

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. It is a simple question of relevance. The minister was asked whether the job was advertised. He simply talked about `as positions arise we will fill them'. He was asked why the job was not advertised; he is now moving on to other ground. You ought to direct him to be relevant.
—I am sure Senator Bolkus is addressing it.
—No, he is not.
—Order! I have made a judgment that he is.
—Casual vacancies are appointed from time to time by the government. With this latest batch a big number of appointments were advertised. Casual vacancies never are.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short asked me about Mr Clothier. The recommendation I got about Mr Clothier was very stark and very clear—and that was that there was someone better for the job. That came from that assessment panel. I would not preclude anyone from a position because of his or her party affiliation.

Senator Short is asking me to interfere and propose someone who was not recommended for a position because Senator Short has some affinity with him. I will not do that. The stench comes from the other side of the parliament. Senator Short is the one blackguarding people's reputations; he is the one who ought to go outside this parliament and do so if he really believes in his conviction.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and follows on from the comment made by the minister to the Senate yesterday regarding his request to ABARE to conduct a national grain audit, to give the government a clearer picture of the current availability of grain. Can the minister advise us whether he has received any preliminary advice on this matter?

—I have, and I stress that it is preliminary advice. Commonwealth officials are now embarked on a far more detailed examination in a national audit in cooperation with the state authorities. Organisations such as the National Farmers Federation and the Grains Council of Australia are already urgently examining the situation as well. Our preliminary audit has indicated that wheat stocks will be sufficient to cover domestic wheat demands until the 1994-95 crop becomes available. Even allowing for around two million tonnes of exports, and that is going on the most pessimistic forecast for crop production, we will have enough grain in aggregate—and I stress aggregate—to meet all of our domestic food and feed requirements. But this is not the situation on the ground. That is simply to do with total tonnages.

PARA.TAB: There will be significant grain shortfalls in the states of Queensland and New South Wales. These will have to be met by imports from Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria, and without question in some cases from overseas. The importation of some of the higher quality wheats, such as durum wheat, will have to be considered. Applications have already been received for around 130,000 tonnes of durum wheat to be imported. Those applications are currently being considered.

The importation in some circumstances of feed grain also is, in my view, a sensible option that will have to be considered as part of a national strategy to ensure regional grain shortages are met in the most efficient and, I stress, cost-effective way possible. It will make more sense in some circumstances for high quality grain from Western Australia suitable for premium prices in exports to be used for that rather than using it as feed grain when feed grain can be imported at a lower cost.

Applications for the import of 120,000 tonnes of sorghum and 10,000 tonnes of maize have already been approved. I must say that I am profoundly disappointed that the ever worsening drought has caused the situation to reach this stage. Clearly, imports have to be considered now as the most efficient and cost-effective way, in some circumstances, of tackling the problem of feed shortages, especially as some domestic prices are now above import parity.

I stress, however, that AQIS is working closely with grain users and in close consultation with the Grains Council of Australia to develop effective quarantine protocols to facilitate such trade, while retaining—as we must—our quarantine integrity. The Australian Wheat Board and state grain marketers are managing supplies to ensure that domestic demand is met. Shipments of grain from South Australia and Western Australia to the eastern states are already taking place. ABARE is planning a special crop report for release in early November to update figures for the winter crop grain production. This would normally have been released in December.

Farm families have already begun applying for the much needed financial relief offered by the government's drought assistance package. I was advised yesterday that some 2,500 applications have already been received in Queensland, and so far 1,200 applications have been received in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Trade. The minister has made a lot of claims here today about the big benefits for Australia of free trade. He might be right in the long run, but what answer does he give to the claims made at the Women, Power and Politics Conference by Canadian economist Professor Marjorie Griffin Cohen that free trade agreements and the opening up of world markets were `dangerous to women and other disadvantaged groups'? What answer does he give to her claim that the wishes of people, as expressed through the actions of elected democratic governments, are being superseded by international trade rules? I am not saying that Australia should stand aside from this. I am saying: how can you or anybody else be sure at the moment that the present international economic order will not create growing gender inequity and the loss of civilised society, as many women at the conference fear? The minister might laugh, but some people do not place blind trust in everything.

—I was smiling only because I was hoping to get the question. One thing that is true is that nobody can guarantee that the benefits of free trade will be fairly distributed in the societies. It may well be that women will in some instances not gain a fair share of the benefits in Australia, Canada or anywhere else. Nobody can guarantee within the countries in question how the benefits will flow.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that I thought Professor Griffin Cohen's arguments left a bit to be desired. She was, for example, concerned about the great loss of jobs in Canada. That does not accord with the statistics that I have seen. But, even if that were true, it would only be because there is a big upsurge of jobs in Mexico. That is the first problem with Senator Kernot's argument.

The second problem is that all Professor Griffin Cohen's concerns relate to NAFTA. Nobody made Canada join NAFTA. Canada made a sovereign decision to join. We have had a free trade agreement for a very long time with New Zealand. None of those adverse implications have followed because of the nature of the agreement. If I might say so, the reason that they have not is that we have not tried to hang off CER all sorts of social and other elements, which is what the Australian Democrats continually seek to do.

Because CER does not have all of those bells and whistles, it does not have all of those consequential implications. CER has been a significant net plus for both countries. There is a great advantage: CER does not have any of those restrictions. There is nothing in any free trade agreement that Australia has joined or is contemplating joining that would have the sorts of consequences that Professor Griffin Cohen has said.

On the basis of the assessments I have seen I think it is highly unlikely that NAFTA will have those consequences, but that is a matter for Mexico, the United States and Canada. They all chose to join, and they negotiated the terms and conditions. They are not terms and conditions that we would necessarily have negotiated in a free trade agreement for Australia, but there is nothing inherent in them that discriminates against women or other disadvantaged people.

If it is true that the benefit of employment is flowing to Mexico—I am not absolutely sure that is correct; it is an assertion that Ross Perot made, which is hotly contested but about which this professor makes her assertion, and she may be right—it is a redistributive element. It is going from the more affluent to the less affluent. I thought Senator Kernot would applaud that. Certainly the Mexican government thinks that thousands of jobs are flowing there. The United States government thinks thousands of jobs are going there. We think that they are probably correct.

Free trade agreements of themselves generate more economic activity and more opportunity. One of the great advantages of the GATT is that it has generated opportunities for people in the poorest countries. A significant number of influential women are involved in the negotiation of it—for example, the principal negotiator representing the United States—and of course significant countries in our region. So it certainly was not some exclusively male conspiracy to disadvantage women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Carla Hill.

—That is right. It is possible that the benefits will be unfairly distributed in some countries. There is nothing that the trade agreement can or, frankly, should do about that. That is a matter of domestic policy of those countries. We will be continuing to advocate equitable policies here and there.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Professor Griffin Cohen said that free trade agreements lead to downward pressure on wages and working conditions. She said that that was the way in which they impacted on women. I think we can see that that has happened. I ask the minister: in accepting the reality of GATT, should we not at least say we will monitor its impact here in Australia? Why, then, do we reject the inclusion of social clauses—what the minister calls the bells and whistles? I heard the minister say that we do, but why do we?
—That is what is causing the problem.
—No, in trade agreements arising out of APEC.
—That is what she is complaining about.
—The ones I am pointing to in NAFTA are environmental. Why can we not take a lead from the United States in this respect?

—The problem is that the only agreement containing the things Senator Kernot is concerned about is the one Professor Griffin Cohen is complaining about. The only agreement with those bells and whistles is NAFTA and that is what she is upset about. By definition, that does not solve Senator Kernot's problem. As a result of GATT we have extended an agreement to set up an environmental committee in the World Trade Organisation. That did not exist before, so that is a step forward. We have said that we will play a positive role with regard to the international debate about fair labour standards. We are not convinced that the proposals before us at the moment are the best way to proceed, but we are concerned about fair labour standards and we will continue to take a positive role about it. I do not think GATT and APEC are useful mechanisms for it at this stage, but let us continue to look at the best way to proceed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. I refer to the release yesterday of two surveys on the prospects of the Australian manufacturing industry, one conducted by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the other by the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales and the State Bank of New South Wales. I am sure that senators will be pleased to note that the surveys revealed a very positive outlook for growth in both manufacturing output and employment over the next 12 months. They also show that confidence in the manufacturing sector is very high. While these overall results are encouraging, can the minister confirm whether the expectations of future growth are spread across the diverse range of manufacturing activities? Can the minister also comment on how these findings sit with the government's forecast for economic growth, particularly in relation to jobs growth and inflationary expectations?

—Probably another set of figures should be entered into the debate as well. Yesterday, the ANZ bank published its survey of job advertisements in Australia for the month of September this year. It showed an increase in seasonally adjusted terms of job vacancies in Australia of four per cent, offsetting a one per cent decline in August. The job vacancies index rose by 12.1 per cent for the September quarter, off the back of an 8.6 per cent rise for the June quarter, showing consistent levels of job vacancies arising in the Australian economy. In a year on year comparison it showed that vacancies this year are at a level of 48 per cent higher than they were at the same time last year.

PARA.TAB: Let me now turn to the two surveys of manufacturing activity referred to in the question. The Australian Chamber of Manufactures survey shows that nationally manufacturers are predicting their strongest December quarter for five years, with 91 per cent of firms surveyed expecting to maintain or increase production. In fact, it shows positive trends in all seven key growth indicators. It shows upward trends in production, in sales, in orders, in exports, in profits, in investment, and in employment. It is particularly pleasing that this growth is expected to translate almost immediately into job opportunities as well.

Both surveys anticipate that some 6,000 jobs will be generated in the manufacturing sector in Australia over the next 12 months. These figures come off a very high base indeed. Forty-three per cent of manufacturers surveyed increased their production in the September quarter. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, manufacturing production rose by 8.3 per cent in 1993-94—the strongest yearly growth since the ABS series began.

The surveys show as well that this growth in production is likely to be translated into further export growth, with 32 per cent of firms surveyed expecting to increase their export sales in the December quarter—again, off a high base. Volumes of manufactured exports have been increasing at an average of 9.9 per cent year on year every year since 1986-87. A recent study by the Centre for Strategic Economic Studies in Victoria shows that exports of elaborately transformed manufactured goods—the most complex manufactured goods—have been growing over recent years at a rate of 20.4 per cent a year.

Allan Handberg, the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, drew special attention to the continued strong growth in our exports just recently. It shows that manufactures are not simply switching back to the domestic market as the pace of economic growth maintains its momentum.

I was asked: is this growth going to be shared across industry sectors? The answer to that question is yes—with expectations strongest in the chemical industry, the pharmaceutical industry, printing, motor vehicles, food, beverages and textile industries. The strong trends are spread across all 12 key manufacturing sectors and across all states of Australia.

I was also asked: what impact will this growth have on inflationary expectations? As manufacturing production reaches capacity constraints, one could expect some pressure on input costs, and this has been signalled. However, the survey of the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales and the most recent ACCI Westpac survey conclude that inflationary pressures remain under control. In particular, they point to the fact that growth in new investment and strong competition within the manufacturing sector itself will keep pressure off prices. That is borne out by the survey findings.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the guidelines for child-care accreditation and the implied threat that child-care centres will lose fee relief if they do not apply for accreditation. I have a letter dated 19 September written to the minister by Mrs Anne Young, proprietor of a child-care centre in Victoria, who does not intend to register for accreditation. She asks: when can the 200 families at her centre, which will suffer financially through the withdraw of fee assistance, expect to have this penalty inflicted on them? The minister has not replied to her letter and neither has the National Child-Care Accreditation Council, to which Mrs Young wrote on 29 July. When does the minister intend to stop fee relief to those centres which have not registered for accreditation?

—I have to say that the person who knows best the answer to this is Mrs Young, but I will be very happy to share the answer with the Senate because Mrs Young has had letters written to her and knows very well what the answer is. The reason I can say that confidently is that I have written to every person involved in running a child-care centre explaining to them that, in the light of the confusion about the accreditation program—
—Caused by you.

—No, and Senator Alston can keep his causal remarks to himself. We know who caused the accreditation difficulties and they were not on this side of the chamber. I was resisting saying them, but I thank Senator Alston for that contribution. He can ring up his colleague in the National Party from Victoria. Ask Senator McGauran what he did about it all.

PARA.TAB: All those people were written to and I explained to them that, in the light of the confusion and to make it absolutely beyond doubt, centres would have until 30 June 1995 to register and begin the process of accreditation. Mrs Young knows that very well. Mrs Young is trying to resist to the end, in the face of the fact that something like 2,700 private and community based centres out of 3,200 are now registered. That is what the rest of the private industry and the community based sector feel. They are registered. They are in the process of doing the accreditation and they are finding it a very constructive, informative and useful exercise.

Also, because we are concerned—and Senator Boswell raised this issue in here—to be accurate about the cost of accreditation, we are in the process, further to requests from Senator Chamarette, of introducing an evaluation program of the accreditation system to make sure that we can answer questions about costs.

I have no idea why Mrs Young is refusing to be part of the registering and accreditation process. She has never made that clear. But she knows very well that there is no risk at all of any cutting off of child-care assistance, at least before 30 June 1995, that the process after that is stretched out as much as possible, and that the whole system is designed to encourage participation by centres. This is precisely because I want two things. I want no centre barred from the accreditation process and, therefore, the child care at risk. More importantly, I want to be assured that every centre in this country provides quality child care.
If Mrs Young feels she is providing quality child care, I cannot understand why she does not cheerfully embrace the process like all the other private and community based centres in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cheerfully!

—Yes, cheerfully. I am delighted Senator Hill reminds me. If he knew, as I do, the response of centres that have been part of the accreditation process, he would know that `cheerfully' is the exact word. Both parents and staff report it as a very attractive, interesting and constructive process.

PARA.TAB: If Mrs Young is concerned about this, one would much rather ask Mrs Young why she is still holding out her centres against registering. That is not the view of all the other centres. As I say, 2,700-plus out of 3,000 centres across the country have registered. Mrs Young should feel absolutely assured that the reason I deferred that was to give her and every other centre as long as possible to take their way through the system and make up their minds to become part of the quality system. It is a system that sets this country apart from any other, with a national system of accreditation and quality for our child care—something we are very proud of and we hope Mrs Young will be part of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister may begin to understand why Mrs Young has not `cheerfully' embraced the notion of accreditation when I point out to the minister, as she no doubt knows, that child-care groups in Adelaide recently estimated that extra costs associated with accreditation will be up to $25 per place per week. This is a very large increase on the 88c per place per week claimed by this government. When will the minister admit that her costing has been incorrect, and indeed fallacious?

—If Senator Troeth had been listening, she would have heard that there was no need for a supplementary. As I pointed out, and I have mentioned in response to some of the things that Senator Boswell has raised in this place, we are in the process right now of evaluating the introduction of the accreditation system so as to be accurate about the costs.
—Why didn't you evaluate it beforehand?

—I assure Senator Troeth that the figures from South Australia are inaccurate. Things are claimed in the costs of those estimates that go to state licensing and to things like the time allocated by staff to place information on notice boards for parents, which of course most of us would presume was happening in all centres anyhow. But there are things in those costs that are well outside the accreditation guidelines and a falsely inflated figure.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, it is very important we get the accurate costs of the introduction of accreditation, and that is what we are in the process of doing right now. And in reply to Senator Herron, he should know that it is not possible to evaluate a program before it is established.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and refers to statements made by Minister Bilney after the ICPD conference in Cairo. PARA.TAB: I did publicly announce in a speech I made in Hobart at the ALP national conference that I am currently looking at how plantations can play a role in relieving pressure on native forests while, at the same time, offering significant expansion of the industry's resource base. The study is fully consistent with the national forest policy statement and will involve state and territory conservation councils. I believe it will be significant in progressing the NFPS goals of the full utilisation and expansion of Australia's plantation resource and the NFPS objectives in relation to the development of plantation based industries.

The study will develop an aggregate national overview of the plantation estate, involving the identification of the extent of hardwood and softwood plantations in each state, opportunities for processing this resource, industry expansion opportunities, employment potential and also Commonwealth actions to stimulate an increased emphasis on plantation resource utilisation. It is designed to provide a picture of the extent of the plantation resource nationwide and will identify specific development opportunities which could enjoy the support of both industry and conservation groups. It will also provide the Commonwealth with information on the potential for the ecologically sustainable expansion of industry and employment.

The study does differ substantially from the National Plantations Advisory Committee work, which primarily focused on the development and establishment of new plantations on cleared agricultural land. It also differs from the work of the Resource Assessment Commission, which undertook financial feasibility assessments for possible expansion of the plantation estate and studies that detailed the area of land suitable for new plantation development. This study, by contrast, will focus on the extent of existing plantation estate and will examine means to fully utilise that resource. The consultant who is coordinating the study has already had very positive feedback about the study from industry sources.

A study proposal from Environment Victoria entitled National Plantations: Environment, Industry Development and Employment was first submitted to my department in June of last year. A revised proposal, which was redrafted to fit more directly within the funding guidelines of the environment portfolio, was submitted in February 1994. On 1 April I received that revised study proposal with the recommendation from my department that funding should be granted for the study. I did, however, withhold further action until July, pending receipt of Environment Victoria's audited financial statement for the grants to voluntary conservation organisations program for 1993-94 and until questions raised by Mr Barry Cunningham on the extent of departmental funding to the organisation were answered. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I refer her to the report entitled Red alert which has been put together over some years by Catherine Beauchamp, acting from the Centre for National Corporate Law Research at the University of Canberra. I ask the minister: has CSL been importing human blood or blood derived materials, such as plasma, from other countries for use in the preparation of products for human use? If so, where and by whom were these imported materials tested for infectious agents, and were donors being screened? If reliance was placed on foreign testing, did any of these products come from countries where hepatitis C or other infectious diseases are common? If so, were these products re-tested in Australia before being pooled with Australian derived blood or blood products? Finally, is it possible that infected product found its way onto the Australian or overseas markets as a consequence of slackness in ensuring sterility?

—In reply to that question, I can provide the following information. CSL does bring into Australia plasma from other countries to manufacture blood products for human use in those countries. However, the plasma that comes in is not pooled with Australian plasma or the plasma from other countries. What comes in stays as a separate unit for the treatment and then is sent out again. The products are then returned to the country of origin. To be clear, there is absolutely no pooling of any of that blood. CSL currently brings into Australia plasma for manufacturing blood products from New Zealand, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia, for their respective use. Donors are screened by the local blood transfusion service in the originating country.CSL has requested that donors should be selected using World Health Organisation guidelines.

PARA.TAB: Overseas plasma is not pooled with Australian plasma or plasma from other countries. The products derived from overseas plasma are returned to the country of origin. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has responsibility for implementing human, animal and plant quarantine in Australia.

The Department of Human Services and Health provides policy advice and assists AQIS in discharging its responsibilities in relation to human quarantine. Until early 1993, AQIS referred all import applications for those biological materials that could pose a possible human health risk to the Department of Human Services and Health for advice on appropriate controls to be applied in each instance.

An internal review of human quarantine in controlling the importation of biological materials took place in late 1992. As a result of that, human quarantine, it was agreed, should only be directed or concerned with a limited number of human disease agents and vectors or hosts that are of distinct quarantine concern. Since the implementation of these recommendations, AQIS routinely processes most import applications for biological materials without reference to human quarantine, and in accordance with the standard protocol agreed between AQIS and Human Services and Health.

Imports of blood and other materials of human origin are subject to the requirements of the TGA. Where products are nominated for human use, they must be certified free of human pathogens by the exporting country prior to import into Australia. They are also subject to the International Air Transport Association requirements concerning international air carriage.

CSL uses state-of-the-art technology, I am advised, to ensure that all viruses are eliminated from final product using chemical and heat treatment protocols. Earlier problems associated with Australian blood products did not result from contamination from overseas plasma.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Troeth this day, relating to the accreditation of child care centres.

SPEECH.PARA: It is indeed regrettable that Senator Crowley chose to indulge in personal abuse of those who dare to question the government's accreditation process. I would like to remind her and the government that very real concerns are being raised about the whole accreditation process at the moment by parents and child-care centres. This has been borne out by meetings that I have attended in both Queensland and Sydney, as well as other parts of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The real concerns which are being raised by those parents and proprietors of the child-care centres involve, among other things, the costs of child-care accreditation—this was raised in both Queensland and Adelaide. The costs, as witnessed by the figures that I raised in my question to Senator Crowley, have now been estimated at $25 extra per week per place instead of the 88c per week per place that was first put forward by Senator Crowley during debate last December.

At the meeting I attended in Queensland last month, the audience of child-care proprietors was evenly divided over whether or not the accreditation costs would significantly add to their costs of maintaining their centres. The conclusion that those people came to was that, if those costs did occur, they would have to be passed on to the parents, thereby causing those parents to pay more for their child care.

Some of the other problems that have been raised with me by parents and child-care proprietors include the staff time that will be absorbed in administration of the accreditation process and therefore less time devoted to children. For instance, parents commented on the fact that there was less change and variety in children's pictures on the walls because staff now had to spend a great deal more time preparing paper work to deal with accreditation.

Not only that, it has been pointed out by many commentators—one of whom was Jackie Lacy from the Australian Consumers Association who spoke at the recent EPAC child-care conference in Canberra—that there is a serious deficiency in child-care services in rural and remote areas. Families in those areas simply do not have neighbours or, indeed, in many cases, extended families with whom they can entrust the care of their children while they need to perform other necessary tasks. Neither do they have access to child-care places, and that is an aspect that will have to be looked at very closely by the government.
Ann Sherry, the former assistant secretary of the Office of the Status of Women, made the following comment at the recent EPAC conference on child care:

SPEECH.PARA: If banks were treating consumers in the same way that a lot of consumers feel they are being treated by children's services, we would be out on the streets.

The children's services area is simply not being provided for by the government. Not only that, Jackie Lacy, the speaker from the Australian Consumers Association to whom I referred earlier, talked about `inadequate or inappropriate hours' and claimed that the system was not keeping pace with changes in work patterns.

PARA.TAB: In modern day Australia, we have not as much nine to five work. We have rotating shift work, casual work, on-call work and occasional work. The recent employment statistics show that the turnaround in jobs in recent months is largely in the area of part-time female casual work. The statistics also show that women are still responsible for the arranging of child care, yet they cannot get child-care hours to suit them. Workers need access to child care that matches their needs and work patterns, otherwise we will continue to lose skilled workers from industries. That was shown in a recent Victorian survey. It estimated that half of all respondents indicated that they had been more than one hour late for work or had left more than one hour early because of difficulties with child-care arrangements.

This child-care expenditure package represents $1.4 billion of government expenditure. It is the government's responsibility to see that consumers get what they need. Children are people; they are not a product. They should be dealt with accordingly, so that we get the best value for our dollar.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reply to some of those claims made by Senator Troeth—particularly to the emphasis that suggests our child-care program is in total disarray. It is anything but. Since we came into office, we have increased child-care places from 46,000 to more than 240,000. We have seen a rapid extension of child-care assistance to keep child care affordable, not only for people in the community based sector but also for people using the private centres. That has happened since 1991, with a dramatic increase in places. We introduced the accreditation program, which has seen a national program for quality across all the long-day care centres in this country, except those like Mrs Young's that are not yet prepared to come within the fold.

PARA.TAB: The second thing that Senator Troeth said was that I claimed that it cost 88c per child per week; that the cost of this program is very confused; and that South Australian figures now suggest that the cost is $25. I simply refute that again. If Senator Troeth has a look at the details of those figures—and I suspect that she may have—she should know, but perhaps she does not, that many of the things that are counted in those costs are matters of state licensing regulations, and they are not part of accreditation. They may be costs that centres have to introduce, but they must not be sheeted home to the accreditation process. That is the distinction we have been drawing all along: a distinction that most people fail to see.

Certainly, I think what is important about the South Australian figures is that they were provided with the best intentions in the world and with the intention of trying to find out. This is the very best of what accreditation programs are about—when centres and the government, or the accreditation council, can work together to make clear which costs properly belong to accreditation and which do not. Those are the sorts of things that most centres are finding of great assistance.

I understand that people in South Australia are not being fierce or adamant. Their assessment is that the cost comes to $25. My assessment—and I have only roughly looked at it, but it is the more accurate assessment—makes it clear that some of the things that they are including in that $25 assessed extra cost do not belong to accreditation.

One of those things is the cost of providing information on noticeboards for parents. That is costly in terms of hours used by staff to provide that information. I think we would have expected most centres to provide that, and it would not be seen as an add-on cost due to accreditation. We need to be a bit cautious about these costings. Certainly, the advice that I have is that those figures are again inaccurate because they include the wrong information. I will say again, for the record, that I did not say it was 88c per child per week. That is the best prediction that the Pitcher Partners consultancy firm could provide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you accepted.
—Of course we did, they were based on a—
—Without a trial.

—No. The figures were based on real world experiences of centres at the time. They were the best that we could provide. Of course we could not give real world accreditation; it was not even established then. That is precisely why the evaluation is happening now. It will start as soon as possible after the centres have had six months to register.

PARA.TAB: The other thing is that the benefit, as I said, is cheerful—and that is exactly the word. In fact, it is much more than that; there is excitement in some centres as they implement the accreditation process. Many of the centres which are nervous about it are the ones which are still not registered, not taking the support and the information that the accreditation council can provide for them.

The Australian Consumers Association report on whether child care is up to scratch reportedly said that one in five parents cannot have choice. What the report does not say is that four out of five parents are getting a choice of child-care centre. Also, it does not explain that many parents in rural Australia are very happy to have child care and that they are not really beating a path to my door to say, `Why can't I choose between long day care and family day care?' What they want is access to child care, and they are pleased to have it.

I am not saying there is nothing wrong with child care. In an industry that has grown as much as child care has, clearly things are emerging that we want to iron out, that we want to redress and that we want to improve. Many of the comments by Ann Sherry about children's services pertain far more to the services provided by states and their failure to cooperate with the Commonwealth in getting the best mix between child care and preschool services. Yes, there are some things in the child-care area that need to be addressed. I am addressing them; I have been doing so and I will continue to do so. We must have the very best child-care industry and the best services for parents. I strongly believe that quality care for children should be at the centre of our program.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to blood supply products distributed by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.

SPEECH.PARA: It frequently happens that I miss the call during taking note of answers to questions, but I have never sought an extension of time. On this occasion I do so because of the importance of the matter.

PARA.TAB: To pick up on the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), I point out that in Australia in 1990 there were 30,000 cases of hepatitis C infection known throughout the whole nation; that is, one person in 500. There are currently 1,600 people in Australia with haemophilia with an 85 per cent infection rate with hepatitis C. Where has that infection come from? Clearly that infection has come from inadequately sterilised products with which haemophilia patients are treated. The question of the safety of the products which CSL is putting on the market is very much at issue.

The minister's response to my question was that CSL was not mixing foreign blood with plasma from Australia which had come from Red Cross departments in various states. On 12 March 1986 the Red Cross in fact wrote to CSL asking it not to mix its plasma from foreign sources with plasma from Australia. Mr Neville McCarthy from CSL wrote back on 27 March 1986 defending the practice and saying that no other practice would in fact produce the cheap product, and that if CSL sought to keep the products separate the costs of production would be prohibitive.

In response to that letter, the Red Cross wrote to Mr McCarthy on 2 May 1986 saying that in view of its legal advice in relation to the safety of its products, it was then refusing to use CSL products for the treatment of patients. Therefore, the minister has given an incorrect answer to the Senate. CSL has been mixing foreign plasma with Australian derived plasma and has in fact been using that both overseas and in Australia.

The report Red Alert to which I referred was prepared by Catherine Beauchamp from the Centre for National Corporate Law Research at the University of Canberra. It goes into considerable detail in relation to this matter and specifically draws attention to the fact that infected material was sent back overseas. She quotes an extensive interview with a senior officer from CSL in relation to hepatitis C in Hong Kong in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: What's interesting about that particular issue is that Hong Kong at that particular time didn't test for hepatitis C. . .

In fact, that is quite contrary to what the minister just said, namely that the standards of testing overseas were equal to WHO standards and equal to standards in Australia. The interview went on to say:
. . . so I doubt that Hong Kong did destroy it,—
that is, hepatitis C—

because it's almost endemic in Hong Kong, so since they don't test for hepatitis C in all likelihood the material that they always use in Hong Kong has hepatitis C in it, if you follow the correlation. It's an interesting thing; there are many countries that don't test to the degree they could or should, they use the justification of cost, but in fact in the Hong Kong case I'm inclined to think they didn't destroy it because their approach would be, well, we don't test for hepatitis C anyway, hepatitis C is endemic to our region and therefore they have almost a hundred percent assurance that they have from a thousand donors, that one would have hepatitis C. . .

That is the source of the infection in the mixed plasma, which is imported into Australia and then mixed with Australian plasma which has caused the infection in the haemophilia patients in this country. I believe this report, which I will seek to table so that other senators can have access to it, contains a lot of very important information which needs a great deal more and much closer investigation. I seek leave to table the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Calvert asked me a question in relation to delays in a voyage by the Aurora Australis in Antarctica. I can advise him that the information I gave earlier in question time was correct. On its first voyage in this season, Aurora Australis has successfully delivered supplies and deployed expeditioners to Macquarie Island and Davis stations and conducted important research on sea ice and seals. Some expeditioners have been flown from Davis to Mawson station by long-range helicopter. Both the ship and the long-range helicopters are performing well and all program objectives are being achieved.

PARA.TAB: Aurora Australis arrived at Davis on 27 September, a month earlier than any past voyage, after working very effectively through heavy pack ice. On leaving Davis station, the area was subjected to a blizzard which compacted the pack ice and the vessel had to work through large flows with ridges up to several metres thick. The vessel is now out of the heavy ice and making good progress towards Hobart. The captain of the Aurora Australis advises that there has been no risk to the safety of personnel.

My understanding is the ship was hove to, as I indicated earlier, for three days. The vessel is at present eight or nine days behind schedule. Delays caused by weather and ice conditions are typical of Antarctic operations and allowance for these is included within the overall program. Delays of this nature can be contained within the present budget.

The first voyage of this season has provided valuable information about the ship's performance in heavy ice, and this information will be used in future planning. In the opinion of the captain of Aurora Australis and the Antarctic Division's voyage leader, the vessel can operate effectively at this time of year. It is currently intended to use a second vessel about every third year to assist with heavy cargo. That will also be used for the return of

SPEECH.PARA: past rubbish, which will assist Australia meet its obligations under the Madrid protocol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the minister for his very prompt reply to my question. I must say my information was that the voyage had been delayed by up to 12 days, but I hear now that it is eight days behind schedule. I refer back to the concerns that I showed at estimates in June. I think my concerns are shared by quite a few people at the Antarctic Division. At that time the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think you can very comfortably blame me. I am the minister.

I hope, and I made this point in June in estimates, that we do not have to blame the minister too much. At that time Mr Sayers stated on behalf of the Antarctic Division that this decision to reduce the Antarctic budget by $4.2 million was made in a very short space of time during budget discussions and very little time was given to assess the impact it would have. He said:
I guess, at the end of the day, the government made the decision that the one-ship option was best overall for Australia's interests . . .
That may be the case in the government's opinion, but I can assure honourable senators that that is not the opinion of a lot of the scientists and the people who work in the Antarctic Division.

PARA.TAB: I go back to my genuine concerns, which I share with those people in the Antarctic Division. Although the minister has said that the ship went down a month earlier, that it has not encountered all the heavy ice and extra risks and that there have been no risks to the ship or to people, I remind the minister that things happen in southern waters at the drop of a hat or when least expected, as was borne out by the unfortunate accident of the InCat last weekend.

I am still concerned about the fact that we have only one ship and no backup support. I have made that point continually and I will continue to do so, because what would have happened if that ship had been beset for a greater period and could not extricate itself from the heavy pack ice? The minister has raised the point about blizzards and whatever, but he has not answered the question as to what measures the government has in place to prevent what could not only be a potential disaster for our Antarctic program but could also perhaps place expeditioners at risk.

The minister has admitted that the program has been delayed by eight days. The cost of one of those ships is in excess of $100,000 a day, so if it is delayed by eight days my arithmetic shows that that is $800,000. It will not take too many delays to add up to the $4.2 million that the government is trying to save. The point I am trying to make is that I think it has been pound wise and a penny foolish and, at the end of the day, may rue the decision. I do not blame the Antarctic Division in any shape or form. It is doing its best with what it can. As I said, I will point the finger at the minister and will continue to point the finger at the minister. I am pleased to see that he has big shoulders and is willing to take the blame.

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Day
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President of the Senate and Senators assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: The Anzacs at the Gallipoli landing on 25 April 1915 were instrumental in forging a new identity for Australia. That landing was a lifetime ago but the deeds of those Anzacs of 1915-18 still speak a message of selfless service and sacrifice that will last forever.

Anzac Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return, but in so doing carried for the remainder of their lives the scars of these experiences.

It is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom.

On Anzac Day, we salute not only the spirit of the Anzacs but, in paying tribute to them, we take the opportunity to dedicate ourselves to striving for our country as they did and to upholding their finest qualities of courage, commitment, endurance and mateship.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate urge the Government to declare Anzac day as Australia's National Day of Commemoration and that it be held on 25 April in each year, and on no other day.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—The Deputy President has received a letter from Senator Ian Macdonald proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

The subservience of the Keating Labor Government to the unelected party bosses of the ALP, which compels it to govern on behalf of the factions in the Labor movement to the detriment of the nation as a whole.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a proud tradition of democracy, but I and members of the coalition have been concerned that in recent times an un-Australian element has crept into our democratic institutions in Australia. It is for this reason that the coalition has proposed this matter of public importance today.

PARA.TAB: Every third-rate film or public showing has a sequel or a return. I remember many years ago—and I am sure my colleagues will remember too—the very graphic photos of the ALP conference; of the ALP determining policy with its leaders locked outside the door of the room where the decisions were being made.

In a horror sequel to that third-rate production so many years ago we now have the Hobart ALP national conference where, although some of the elected leaders now sit inside, they are still told what to do by unelected people, and they are told how they should govern Australia and how they should react and vote in parliament. This has become endemic in the way this nation has been governed.

We only have to look at the recent debate on uranium in this country to understand how the elected people of the parliament, but particularly those who occupy the government benches at the present time, simply are unable to govern in the best interests of the nation but are required instead to govern in the interests of the ALP factions.

As you would be well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, many Labor politicians, those in power—for example, the Prime Minister, the Minister for Resources and the Minister for Primary Industries, who occupies a seat in this chamber, to name just three—were determined to overturn the ALP's quite ridiculous three-mine uranium policy.

These three elected politicians clearly understood the stupidity of that three-mine policy. The policy says that uranium from three mines—two, in fact, as it is—is okay, it will not cause any problems, but that uranium from other mines is no good. We have good uranium from three mines and every other piece of uranium is bad.

These three men—the Prime Minister, the Minister for Resources, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, from this chamber, who represents the Northern Territory—wanted to change that. Senator Collins has been quite vocal and open about the need to change that policy. The Prime Minister, as well, understands the stupidity of that policy and the damage that that policy is doing to our international credibility and standing, particularly in the business and finance world.

Those three elected parliamentarians understood the absolute necessity for a change in that stupid, hypocritical policy. They clearly want it to change. Senator Collins, in this chamber, has said on a number of occasions that he wants to change that.

It was also clear that the Prime Minister of our nation wanted that change. But were they able to do so? Were they able to debate that matter in this chamber, in this parliament or in cabinet and determine that that policy should be changed? Were they, as the elected parliamentarians, able to make decisions in the interests of Australia and Australians? They were not. They were told by a group of 100 or so, I understand—perhaps half of that—unelected people, who have absolutely no accountability to the Australian public whatsoever, that they were not allowed to do what they knew was best for the Australian public.

Were they told that at the ALP conference out of a concern for the environment? Did the powerbrokers of the ALP tell them they could not do that out of concern for world peace? Did they do it out of a real and genuine interest in disarmament? Did the powerbrokers of the ALP tell the Prime Minister that he could not change the policy out of some real concern for pollution?

Or did the powerbrokers make their decision for none of those reasons but simply as a payback to show a particular mining company in this country that it could not ignore the union movement, that it could not create an enterprise agreement which would give good wages and conditions to its workers and which would help the company and Australia's international competitiveness but without union involvement?

The union bosses did not like that. They were determined to ensure that that company was punished for trying to avoid the unions. To make that company understand that it could not buck the unions, the unions and the ALP bosses told the elected Prime Minister that they could not change the three-mine uranium policy which the Prime Minister and most of his ministers understand is an absolute stupidity.

It is an ugly day for Australia when a group of union bosses, because their union was not getting its way with one of Australia's leading companies, hold Australia to ransom—simply say to Australia, `We don't care what's good for Australia. We don't care that changing that policy would create $1 billion in export income over the next 10 years.'

This policy, if changed, would create many jobs for Australians. A couple of Aboriginal communities desperately want to open a mine to give themselves jobs, and an ability to get out and earn a living in this world. The union bosses say, `We're not interested in that and we're not going to agree with the Prime Minister.'

In the ALP conference in Hobart we have a sequel to that previous third-rate horror show: we have the return of the faceless men who determine what is best for Australia's future. What happened to the people who were elected? I am very pleased to see that the people talking in this debate—Senators Faulkner, Loosley and Murphy—all come from the organisation of the ALP, so they will be well aware of how this happens.

What has happened to Australian democracy? At least those three, on this occasion, were elected by the people of Australia. They are here to make the decisions, not these unelected people who control the matter in Hobart—the union heavies who know that their power is about to dissipate, that no longer will they have the control that they used to have if Australia keeps going the way it should go. Those people are doing everything in their power to ensure that Australians are governed not by elected representatives but by unelected backroom people.

Not only was there the CRA deal—where the unions forced the government to make a decision that the government knew was not in the interests of Australia—but also there was the deal forced by the union movement and those unelected people on the ANL. There was also the deal about reining in the ABC, in which the minister, knowing what the decision was, had to get the permission of these unelected people to change the way that Australia needs to be governed and the policies that need to be implemented.

Why did this government allow those union people—those unelected people—to control it? One reason is that this government, to remain in power, needs the money and the manpower that those unions provide to spread the lies, as they did at the last election. One only has to look anywhere to see the way that the unions participated in manpower and—(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
