TALK.START.PARA: —What really says it all about the Liberal Party is the fact that we required two letters from Senator Macdonald to communicate to the Deputy President his wish to raise a matter of public importance under standing order 75.

PARA.TAB: I table the first, which was grammatically incorrect. Senator Macdonald forgot to put a verb in the sentence. No-one could understand it—even his own troops. So they all got together and the other letter has a heading with `revised' on it. After a Liberal Party collective, the second one has now been put in and I table it, grammatically correct at last.

Is it not good that the Liberal Party has got something right? It has taken a while, but finally Senator Macdonald got in a matter of public importance to the Deputy President and put it in English. That is terrific!

The motivation for this matter of public importance is very transparent: the Liberal Party, the Tories over there, are really concerned about a TV series about to start this week—tomorrow night I think—which will run for five weeks. Some are looking forward to it. We will get a glimpse of the organisational ability of Sir Robert Menzies.

This series will really be fun. It will talk about what Sir Robert Menzies has been able to achieve. Not only was he so good at organising the Liberal Party that he organised nobody else to challenge him while he was Prime Minister and leader of the Liberal Party, but also he managed to see that carry through for 30 years afterwards.

Who would have thought that Menzies had that level of influence that there is still no-one able to challenge him 30 years later? Of course, this television series will really show the Australian people what an absolutely hopeless lot those opposite are—what a pathetic group of individuals they are.

The fact is that those opposite have not been able to put a coherent policy position to the Australian people for decades—and anything they have put forward has been rejected by the people, election after election. They have the hide to come in here and talk about the lack of organisational ability of the Labor Party. Oh, how jealous they are of our performances! It has been really interesting over the past week to see all the commentators sifting through the entrails of the Liberal Party organisation. What is the conclusion they have all come to? It is that those opposite are pathetic and leaderless, and do not have a clue. They have a hell of a lot to learn from the Australian Labor Party.

What are the features of today's Liberal Party members? Let us have a look at them. Liberal Party members are identified not only by their political opponents but also by those commentators who happen to be members of their political party—even by their supporters around the country. What are the characteristics of the modern Liberal Party? One is that there is no federal organisation. It is just a conglomerate of abysmal, pathetic, unfunded state organisations that run their own agendas because they know how hopeless the federal Liberal Party is. It also has no policy development or policy discussion. There is no development of a party manifesto or platform—none. What else?

TALK.START.PARA: —No direction.

—There is no direction. There is no way for the party at either an organisational level or a parliamentary level to come to a united and constructive position on anything. It is racked by division and differences; and those opposite have the gall to come into this chamber and waste hours of the Senate's time talking about the internal affairs of the Labor Party. Not only are they hypocrites, they are fools. The way they have tried to deal with these problems is to shuffle the figurehead around. They have had more changes of leaders than most people have had hot dinners. They have even flirted with people outside the parliamentary Liberal Party. What a tremendous own goal it would have been if they had decided to run with John Elliott. They flirted with Joh Bjelke-Petersen. That would have been another classic own goal. The only thing I can say about John Elliott and Joh Bjelke-Petersen is that they would have been better than the people they chose. That is the only thing those two had to offer.

PARA.TAB: What have those opposite done of recent times? They have decided to move from the failures of the past—the Hewsons, the Howards, the Peacocks and the Frasers—to Alexander Downer; the final triumph of organisational capacity. They have to be having themselves on. They are the only political party in the world that could have someone like Bronwyn Bishop as a serious pretender to the throne. This is the sort of party we are dealing with; this is the mob that has come into this chamber to criticise us. They have to be kidding.

We talk about differences between the factions. This very unhappy coalition of one extraordinarily divided political party, the Liberal Party, and the National Party conservative rump has been trying to move towards government. What does the National Party provide? This morning Tim Fischer was bemoaning the difficulties he is having in keeping his own troops in line in respect of the coalition's position on the sexual privacy legislation. He was bemoaning the problems he has—and they are substantial.

There are numerous examples of the problems being faced by this non-faction ridden party, the Liberals. There are the Western Australian uglies. I know that Senator Crichton-Browne is not involved in faction activity. Every senator knows that. All his friends, such as Senator Panizza who is about to be rolled in pre-selection for the Senate, know about that. There is no Tasmanian fundamentalist faction in the Liberal Party. Senator Watson knows that. There is no mad right from the Queensland Liberal Party, supported by Senator Ian Macdonald. There is no Urbanchich faction in New South Wales, which Senator Bishop and others have been sponsoring for a long time.

The so-called group of lefties in New South Wales does not exist. Then there is the boofhead faction from Victoria. That is not real, is it? Come off the grass. Those opposite are snivelling hypocrites. Who do they think they are kidding coming into this chamber and criticising our party, which is the best organised, best managed political party in the country. They have a hide—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Ian Macdonald

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am reluctant to interrupt the debate but standing order 194 does require the senator speaking in a debate to be relevant and to address the question. In case Senator Faulkner is not able to read, the question that the Senate is discussing is as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: The subservience of the Keating Labor government to the unelected Party bosses of the ALP, which compels it to govern on the part of the factions in the Labor Movement to the detriment of the nation as a whole.

Senator Faulkner has now used nine minutes of his 15 minutes so far—so I have given him a fair opportunity to get on to the subject—and not once has he mentioned the matter under debate, not once has he mentioned the way the ALP is controlled by unelected people. He spent his whole time speaking about some other matter. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to rule on standing order 194, which I have identified. The minister should at least be relevant and should talk to the subject before the chair, rather than to something which is completely off the point.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I do not uphold the point of order because the proposal deals with the internal affairs of political parties. Senator Faulkner has been contrasting the two political parties that are under discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. The minister may throw his arms in the air but he has twice used the word `hypocrite' in respect of us. I believe it is unparliamentary—
—I withdraw.
—You should ask him to withdraw it—and the comment by Senator Loosley should be withdrawn.
—Senator Faulkner has withdrawn. I did not hear the comment from Senator Loosley. If you want it withdrawn, Senator Panizza, you should indicate what you have objected to.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I used the expression, `Come on.' If that offends Senator Panizza, I withdraw it.

—The one thing those opposite have proved in the last 15 years that they cannot do is `come on'—they have gone backwards. Of course it is offensive to Senator Panizza and, I am sure, to every other member of the Liberal Party. But fancy this disaster of a political party, a so-called modern opposition, coming in here and criticising the Australian Labor Party, in this time-wasting matter of public importance, for being more organised than it is. That is what those opposite are saying. They are criticising the Labor Party for being a better managed, more coherent and more effective political force than they are. They are very unhappy about it. It will stay the same; I think I can promise that.

PARA.TAB: I say to honourable senators opposite that they have had it; their political organisation has had it; and we are more than happy—apart from the fact that it wastes everyone's time—to debate this till the cows come home. I think it is very foolhardy of them to draw comparisons between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party. That is really dopey politics. It is the sort of thing that has characterised their performances over the past decade and a half.

We have in the Labor Party an effective and rational policy making process, and those opposite are very jealous of it. In fact, half the members of the Liberal Party are suggesting that they ought to formalise their factions because the model of the Labor Party is one that they are extraordinarily jealous of. Who would want to join those over there on that side of the chamber? What a lacklustre, hopeless lot they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would find that we've got more members than you if you checked the figures.

—If Senator Panizza went through those doors and over to the House of Representatives he would find that we are still firmly ensconced in government, and we have been for a very long time. What sorts of adjectives are being applied to the Liberal Party? Disastrous, venal, hopeless, incompetent—those are the sorts of adjectives that the Australian people, the media, political scientists and other observers are applying to the political party of those opposite, and they are right. That is the judgment of the Australian people. Here Liberal Party members are, criticising the organisational capacity of the Labor Party at a time when the leader of the federal Liberal Party only just manages to scrape into double figures in terms of his approval rating. That is how those opposite compare with us.

PARA.TAB: There is ever-growing evidence of a lack of talent on the opposition benches in this chamber. We have those in the Liberal Party who have an understanding of the political process in this country—people like Kroger and so forth—deciding they do not want to be any part whatsoever of those opposite. They are on the ropes, and everyone knows they are on the ropes.

I will tell the Senate what the ALP organisational abilities have delivered: a system which is broadly representative; which allows for a range of philosophical points of view; which allows policy debates to be conducted vigorously, constructively, comprehensively and openly; which allows all participants to be properly involved in the decision making process, where people know what their rights, obligations and responsibilities are; and which allows all members of the party to have real policy input and an opportunity to make a difference and make parliamentarians account for their actions. Liberal Party senators are jealous, and so they should be. They can eat their hearts out. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Faulkner: no, we are not jealous at all. Senator Faulkner mentioned that some on this side of the house are talking about formalising the factions, and that might be so. But I will tell government senators what the difference is: when we talk about those factions, we talk about them being elected by the people of Australia. We do not talk about those factions having members who are not elected by the people of Australia. That is really the thrust of this proposal.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the recent ALP conference, we will notice that Bill Ludwig, the national President of the Workers Union, was reported as controlling between 10 and 15 votes out of 102. I would like to see where Bill Ludwig sits in this chamber or in the other place. This is the very point we are on about.

I have been involved in the Liberal Party organisation for many years and I can see the benefits in managing different points of view. But one thing we have never gone for is having unelected people having a say in how the government of the day—that would be a Liberal government—would handle things. Graham Richardson wrote in the Bulletin of 11 October 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: In Labor's platform, mineral exploration is now permitted in national parks, although this occurred more by accident than design. More than half of those who voted for the amendment thought they were restoring the original words of the platform when they were in fact inserting key new words.

So much for Senator Faulkner's well-run party. There we have a classic case where former Senator Richardson acknowledged that there was a stuff-up. People did not even know what they were voting for. Jennifer Hewett, in reference to the conference, stated in an article in the Financial Review dated 30 September 1994:
Paul Keating was praising the triumphant pragmatism of the ALP. By yesterday morning a lot of very irritated delegates were calling it much more unpleasant names.

Again, so much for Senator Faulkner's well-run party. The thrust of this proposal is that the people of Australia are being governed by people who are not in this chamber or the other place. I mentioned the influence of Bill Ludwig. There is also the influence of Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the ACTU, who made his influence felt on uranium mining issues and the rescue of ANL.

PARA.TAB: I might just dwell on a couple of matters where policy has been changed by this so-called well-run machine that Senator Faulkner referred to. Firstly, we have the privatisation of airports. Laurie Brereton wanted to sell the federal airports. The unions would not agree and then brokered a deal which saw that the airports would be tendered out for lease—again an influence from an outside body. I note in today's Financial Review an article headed `ACTU proposes radical revamp of copyright law'. I suppose that now means that the government's platform will be dictated by the ACTU and the government will revamp its whole standing on copyright law.

Let us get back to the ANL. Bill Kelty, another one of the old mates of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who was angered by Mr Brereton's pre-emptive attempts to shut out the Maritime Union from ANL discussions, believed that the Maritime Union played an important organisational and financial role in securing Labor's 1993 election victory and therefore could not be overlooked. Brereton, as the Senate would know, comes from a different faction. What we had there was another brokering of a deal. Eventually the minister publicly retreated and threw a fistful of dollars at the problem.

Perhaps the greatest example of the Prime Minister of the day being dictated to by the conference was the three mines uranium policy. The Prime Minister would say that he did not really have his heart in it, that he was not really involved in the matter. Nonetheless, he was rolled and we had a situation where the so-called well-run machine fell into disarray because the Right disintegrated in the face of the Left. What we had again was the subservience of the government to unelected people.

In the factions, which Senator Faulkner mentioned, there are people who have not been elected to this parliament. That is the difference between Senator Faulkner's party and the party which I stand for. An essential difference is that, in relation to the Liberal Party, the electors get what they see.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put a bit of heart into it.

—In Senator Murphy's case and in the case of those opposite, they get an ALP conference and they do not know which way it will go. The uncertainty which exists because the Labor Party's factional system is experiencing problems is no good for this country. What those opposite will have from conference to conference is uncertainty in what policy they will be adopting. I just wonder whether the government of the day will have the guts and fortitude at the polls to tell the people of Australia, `Look, sorry, boys. This is our policy for the election, but we're not sure what we're going to be told to do at the next ALP conference. We're not sure what we're going to be told to do by the factional managers and factional participants, who have not been elected by this parliament.' That is really what this system is.

PARA.TAB: The system has changed. It has gone a long way from the old days of the 1950s and 1960s. I believe that, as a result, the integrity and ideals of the Labor Party have suffered a great deal. Labor Party members have become victims of apparatchiks. They have become victims to machinery people who do not care much for ideals or the old-fashioned Labor principles. All they are concerned with is staying in government at any cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Faulkner pointed out, Senator Ian Macdonald's matter pursuant to standing order 75 would have to be nothing short of an act of political stupidity. He had to write the letter twice. I know Senator Faulkner tabled both letters to the President, but I would like to read out the first one because when we received it we could not understand it either. In the second paragraph it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The subservience of the Keating Labor Government to the unelected Party bosses of the ALP, which compels it to govern on behalf of the factions in the Labor Movement to the nation as a whole.
We thought for a while that we might amend it to read `for the nation as a whole' and we would probably support it.

PARA.TAB: The one thing that the Labor Party can be very proud of is that we always take account of the views of the rank and file. Senator Ellison says that he would take no account and would allow no participation, but that is not what John Hewson said and it is not what Alexander Downer—Alexander oops—is saying. Alexander Downer is now moving to have the Liberal Party federal executive given powers to enable it to override the states and so on. It would be very interesting to see how Senator Ian Macdonald might vote in that situation.

Those opposite speak about faceless men in the ALP, but let us have a look at the Liberals. In Senator Ian Macdonald's own state, when the Bjelke-Petersen government was in power we had Mr Sparkes, the white shoe brigade and the open drawer at Joh's desk for the brown paper bag. What sort of process of influence was that within the parliamentary system in Queensland? Does it work the same for those opposite now? Is that how they work?

What about the Liberals' good old former president, none other than John Elliott—pig's arse? What about him? He said, `pig's arse'; he would not be president of the Liberal Party any more. Of course he would not. Not only does he have enough difficulties of his own but also he would not want to be on a horse that is going to lose again and again.

One would have to wonder how Sir Robert Menzies could have such influence over such a long period. So many of those opposite probably go to bed each night, say a little prayer and hope that in the morning they will wake up and he will be back. The Liberal Party has no vision, no plan, no real direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody is listening.
—As Senator Loosley said, nobody is listening. We can see that by the number of people who are in this chamber. There is one person in the press gallery and there are a few in the public gallery.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, if Senator Murphy concedes, quite rightly, that nobody is listening to him and he is only repeating what Senator Faulkner has already said, we would give leave for him to table Senator Faulkner's speech and we can get on with the business.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have to come in here and treat this particular proposal with the contempt that it deserves because it is a total waste of the Senate's time. It is a waste of taxpayers' money. Senator Ian Macdonald does not have the capacity to come in here and put up something that is worthy of debate. If he really had something of substance or relevance we would not mind debating it with him. He comes in here with matters pursuant to standing order 75 time and time again, but he never has one matter of substance. Not one. It reflects very badly on him. I hope some people might be listening to this; they might just see the stupidity of the action taken by Senator Ian Macdonald and realise the time that has been wasted when the Senate could be dealing with something so much more relevant to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murphy is a new senator and there is a lot more that he has to learn in his first term—as we all do. We are on air, we are being broadcast, so Senator Murphy can rest assured that a great number of people—I am told there could be as many as 30,000 at any one time—are listening to the Senate. Those people have heard that half Senator Murphy's speech was one big joke; he smiled and laughed all the way through. If that is any indication of how he is going to treat his parliamentary responsibilities—making light of a matter of public importance—he had better watch out for his preselection by the faceless men.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the chamber concede that it is the very nature of politics that there are different views—perhaps termed factional views—on social and economic issues. There is a great deal of benefit in finding a system that best manages it. As Senator Ellison pointed out, it has never been our intention to be managed from outside this parliament, as is the case with the ALP. Major decisions such as that relating to uranium policy should be taken within this parliament. I am referring to decisions that influence the wealth of this country to the tune of billions of dollars. Key decisions and important decisions should be made within this parliament.

While from time to time members of the Canberra press gallery write articles about the Labor factions and how well managed they have been in preventing and avoiding political brawls in the life of this government, that is no longer the case. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 333 of the committee, entitled The sale of Aussat. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the opportunity to table the 333rd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which reviews audit report No. 33 of 1992-93, The Sale of Aussat and best practice for the sale of Commonwealth assets. The completion of the Aussat sale in December 1991 marked an important step in the development of Australia's telecommunications system. The sale was coupled with the granting of a general telecommunications licence to the successful bidder, Optus Communications, thus removing Telecom's longstanding monopoly in this field. The present duopoly arrangements are scheduled to terminate on 30 June 1997, when the industry will be exposed to even wider competition.

PARA.TAB: The sale was made difficult by several factors which combined to lessen the Commonwealth's bargaining position. Aussat had by the time of the sale accumulated debts totalling some $800 million, with little prospect for improvement and one of the two bidding consortia had disintegrated—three of the four partners had withdrawn. Finally, there was a deadline imposed for completion of the sale.

In order to make Aussat more attractive, the company's debts were repaid by the Commonwealth and a second telecommunications licence was added to the sale. The principal findings of the audit report were that the sale was completed on time, in accordance with the government's objectives and at an acceptable price. The committee agrees with these findings. Indeed, the committee believes that those negotiating the sale on behalf of the Commonwealth did a very good job in difficult circumstances.

In conducting its review, the committee took a forward looking approach and focused on aspects of the sale which affect the Commonwealth's future interests. Two areas were of particular interest to the committee. The first was to ensure that appropriate mechanisms were in place to monitor the future performance obligations entered into by Optus. The second was to draw lessons from the Aussat sale experience which may help improve future sales processes.

As part of the sale agreement, Optus undertook to achieve certain goals in the period up to the end of the telecommunications duopoly. The main undertakings were: to extend its fixed and mobile telecommunications network throughout Australia, achieving certain `network roll-out' milestones at various dates up to June 1997; and to achieve certain levels of investment, Australian content, and expenditure on training and research and development.

One of the committee's concerns was that, at the time of sale, the Department of Communications did not have in place any arrangements with which to monitor Optus's network roll-out performance. By way of contrast, the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, as it was at the time, had an extensive system in place to monitor Optus's industry development undertakings.

The committee acknowledges that the Department of Communications now has in place an acceptable monitoring system. However, the committee believes it to be important that such arrangements be negotiated as an integral part of a contract for the sale of an asset. It is inappropriate and unnecessarily risky for the Commonwealth to seek to negotiate such arrangements after a sale has been concluded.

A second lesson to be drawn for future sales is that any provision for `excusable events' should be clearly defined so that the rights and obligations of all parties are clearly understood. The committee explored the Audit Office's concern that the excusable events clause in the Aussat sale deed could threaten the timing of Optus's network roll-out. This stemmed from the vague, broad nature of the clause and the limited and inflexible range of responses available to the Commonwealth in the event of any network roll-out delays.

At the public hearing into the sale, the committee was pleased to receive advice from Optus that there had been no excusable events to date and that Optus had agreed to give the department forewarning of any intention to invoke the excusable events provisions. The committee sympathises with Audit's concern in relation to the breadth of the excusable events provision in the Aussat sale contract, but accepts that the provision was the best available in the circumstances.

The Commonwealth's relatively poor bargaining position also contributed to the absence of any liquidated damages provisions with the contract. The committee was advised by the department that inclusion of such provisions was considered by Optus to be a `deal breaker'. The committee was informed, however, that, despite the absence of such contract enforcement provisions, there were various commercial incentives for Optus to fulfil its obligations. These were: the opportunity for fines under the licence agreement if Optus failed to meet its network roll-out milestones—the licence conditions are monitored by Austel; secondly, Optus's acknowledgment in the roll-out deed that failure to meet its obligations will yield the Commonwealth pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages; and, thirdly, most severe of all the loss of favourable introductory interconnect rates with Telecom if the Optus system is connected to Telecom's after certain specified dates.

The committee was advised during the public hearing that Optus was in fact substantially ahead of its roll-out schedule. Nevertheless, the committee notes that towards the end of network roll-out—as less profitable areas are reached and as the end of the duopoly approaches—the commercial imperatives for Optus could weaken. This is not to say that Optus would forsake its obligations—as I have said already Optus has more than met its obligations to date. Rather it is to say that the `reserve powers' of regulatory penalties could become more important to the Commonwealth than they are at present.

The committee therefore considers that in future sales the Commonwealth should seek to enforce performance covenants through a combination of commercial and regulatory penalties or incentives. In conclusion, the committee believes that although there are aspects of the Aussat sale agreement which are less than ideal from the Commonwealth's perspective, the Commonwealth achieved the best possible outcome in the circumstances. Those involved in the second telecommunications carrier selection team should be congratulated.
The audit report and the Committee's review have highlighted issues which the committee hopes will assist in any future sales of Commonwealth assets. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CLASSIFICATION (PUBLICATIONS, FILMS AND COMPUTER GAMES) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this Bill provides for the classification of films, publications and computer games.

The agreement of the States and Territories to the Bill proceeding provides a unique opportunity, on a co-operative national basis, to make Australia's censorship laws more uniform and simple, with consequential benefits to the industry and the public.

The Bill is the Commonwealth's contribution to revising the current legislative structure in cooperation with the States and Territories. The Bill, when enacted, will not be able to be brought into force until complementary State and Territory enforcement legislation is enacted. The model State and Territory legislation is currently being drafted.

Australia's censorship laws are in an unsatisfactory state. They comprise Regulations under the Customs Act 1901, which, among other matters, establish the Censorship Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review, a Commonwealth administered Australian Capital Territory Ordinance and State and Territory legislation. The Censorship Board has, for many years, performed the classification function for films under State and Territory legislation.
There are considerable difficulties in administering the current laws as they are unnecessarily complicated and not uniform.

With this background in mind, the Australian Law Reform Commission was asked to report on how the laws could be simplified and made more uniform and efficient while preserving the co-operative nature of the current scheme.
The Commission presented its Report on Censorship Procedure in 1991 and the Bill has been prepared, in consultation with the States and Territories, following the recommendations in that Report.

Reflecting the co-operative nature of Australia's censorship laws, the Bill is for a Federal Act for the Australian Capital Territory under section 122 of the Constitution. The Australian Capital Territory self-government legislation reserved to the Commonwealth the power to classify material for censorship purposes. This was to ensure that a national censorship scheme was preserved.

The Bill will establish the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board and set out the procedures for classification. Classification decisions will be made in accordance with the National Classification Code and Guidelines to help apply the Code. Both the Code and the Guidelines must be agreed between the Commonwealth, States and Territories.

Under the new scheme it is proposed that State and Territory legislation will adopt, in enforcement laws, the classification decisions made under the Commonwealth Act. It is the State and Territory legislation that will, in effect, govern the submission of films, publications and computer games to the Classification Board for classification. It will also deal with the consequences, in the respective jurisdictions, of the different classifications given by the Board to films, publications and computer games.

In recommending the structure reflected in the Bill, the Commission observed that it accurately reflects, and maintains, the balance of responsibilities that has currently been arrived at between Australian jurisdictions. It also recognises that, in relation to the classification criteria and categories, the Commonwealth, States and Territories are equal partners and that policy on these matters is derived from agreement between all jurisdictions.

The Commission noted that the benefit of the new scheme was that `[t]here will be a single procedure, avoiding the overlaps and duplications that presently exist, and the classifiers will derive their powers from a single source, removing the difficulty that they sometimes face now of conflicting legislation from different jurisdictions.'
The new legislative scheme is an excellent example of co-operative Federalism. For example:

The Bill will only apply by its own force in respect of the Australian Capital Territory and the extent to which classification decisions under it have effect in other jurisdictions is a matter entirely for the State or Territory concerned;
The Commonwealth and the States and Territories have equal voting rights in settling the criteria and guidelines under which classification decisions are made;
The States and Territories are given the right to be consulted about appointments to the two Boards; and
The States and Territories will receive a guaranteed share of the revenue from fees collected to assist with enforcement.

In case all States do not agree to adopt the classifications under the Commonwealth Act in relation to films, publications and computer games, the Bill, in order to preserve a national scheme, makes provision for the States and the Northern Territory to confer functions on the Classification Board under their own legislation in accordance with an agreement between the Commonwealth and the jurisdiction concerned.
The Bill is essentially procedural in nature and reflects the current approach to censorship matters agreed by the Commonwealth, States and Territories.

Under the Bill material will continue to be classified on the basis of the principles that adults should be able to read, hear and see what they want, that children should be protected from material likely to harm or disturb them, and that everyone should be protected from exposure to unsolicited material they find offensive. The Bill also introduces a new principle, namely, the need to take account of community concerns about depictions which condone or incite violence, particularly sexual violence, and the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner.
Despite the unsatisfactory state of our current laws, Australia is at the forefront of other comparable countries in its approach to censorship matters.

The basic approach adopted is to give adults sufficient information, through the classifications given to material and the consumer advice provided, to make an informed choice about what they want to see, hear or read and what material they allow their children to have access to.

I was interested to note from a recent Australian Bureau of Statistics survey, commissioned by the Office of Film and Literature Classification, that significant use is made of the classification system by adults in selecting suitable viewing for their children and also for themselves.

In relation to the content of the material to be found in the various classifications, I and my State and Territory counterparts are well aware of the genuine concern in some sections of the community about the amount of violence in films and the possible harmful effects this might have on children and some adults.

Governments have already taken positive action to address community concerns. The measures include the tightening up by Censorship Ministers of the guidelines for the `M' and `R' classifications, the introduction of the new `MA' classification and a stricter regime for the classification of computer games.

The question whether classification decisions reflect community attitudes (and thereby enjoy general community acceptance) is ultimately dependent on the individual and collective decisions of the people who comprise the two classification Boards. There is a need, recognised by all Censorship Ministers, to ensure that the Board members who make the classification decisions on behalf of the community are, as far as practicable, broadly representative of that community. I have been paying close attention to the composition of the current Boards in consultation with my State and Territory colleagues.

To ensure Board members remain aware of community attitudes the Censorship Board has, as recommended by the Law Reform Commission, a continuing community consultation program which includes arranging for ordinary members of the public to come in and review films and indicate the classification and consumer advice they would award to them. This is supplemented by research projects on community standards, the results of which are made available to Board members.

As to the provisions of the Bill itself, I have already mentioned that it establishes the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board. It also contains procedural provisions relating to applications, decision making, notification of decisions and review of decisions. As the Government intends to establish the Office of Film and Literature Classification, which services the two Boards, as a separate business unit, there are also standard financial and accounting provisions in the Bill to achieve this end.

Under the new scheme all films and videos, except those for business, accounting, professional, scientific or educational purposes, must be classified. In relation to publications, the Law Reform Commission recommended that the current voluntary scheme be replaced by a partially compulsory scheme and this is reflected in the Bill. Under this scheme publications will be classified by the new Classification Board, and not departmental officers as at present. A partially compulsory scheme is achieved by, in effect, requiring publications that straddle the Category 1 restricted classification, which is the lowest classification for restricted publications, and the upper end of the Unrestricted category to be submitted for classification. Failure to do so will be an offence under State and Territory legislation. This should result in many more publications being submitted for classification.

In addition, the Bill will enable the Director to call in publications that fall within this class, which are called submittable publications in the Bill, for classification. Failure to abide by the Director's request will be an offence.

The Bill also includes provisions to enable the classification of computer games. An interim scheme to enable computer games to be classified was introduced earlier this year through amendments to the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 which is administered by the Commonwealth. Following the decision of the States and Territories to not allow `X' or `R' classified computer games to be available the Bill makes no provision for these classifications. It also clarifies the definition of `computer game' in response to anomalies arising from the interim scheme that have been brought to the attention of the Government.
Under current arrangements, fees are levied under State and Territory legislation, collected by the Commonwealth and shared equally between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory.

The Bill provides for the Commonwealth to levy classification fees in the future. In return for the States and Territories foregoing their fee powers, and in recognition of their enforcement costs, it is proposed that they each receive the average of their share over the last five years, a total of $600,000 in 1994-95. This amount will be adjusted in future years by the changes in the Consumer Price Index.

The Bill will also enable the Commonwealth to increase, over several years, charges for classification services so that there is substantial cost recovery. This will be done by introducing charges for new initiatives and increasing existing charges to reflect the cost of the service provided, thereby providing savings to the Commonwealth. These changes will not only fund the Government's initiatives to address the community need for readily accessible classification advice but also enable the provision of a more efficient and timely service to clients.

Mr President, I believe this Bill represents a significant advance in an area which has a daily impact on the Australian Community. It is a welcome co-operative initiative between all Australian Governments.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
