DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No. 259 and made under the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The effective aim of the regulations is to allow for ANSTO to condition a quantity of radioactive wastes, which is the responsibility of the Commonwealth, Australian Defence Industries Ltd, and the Australian Radiation Laboratory, and then transport that conditioned waste to Woomera for storage.

PARA.TAB: The rationale for disallowance of these regulations is simple: a risk is associated with the transport and processing of this waste, as with any nuclear waste, and these risks have not been sufficiently considered in the context of normal environmental and planning laws, nor in the wider community through proper consultation. The issue of ANSTO's immunity from proper scrutiny under normal state and territory legislation is also crucial in this context, and I will return to this issue shortly. The environmental, public health and occupational health risks associated with nuclear processes, technology and waste are well known but, unfortunately, are rarely acknowledged by authorities, many of which are part of the nuclear industry—a case of self-regulation.

In Western Australia recently, Dr Stephen Proud, a member of the Medical Association for the Prevention of War, spoke at a media conference about the health effects of uranium and associated nuclear materials. He cited evidence that uranium, for example, affects the genetic make-up of the male sperm and increases the incidence of childhood leukaemia. Radioactive contamination also damages the DNA, which irreversibly creates a legacy for all future generations.

The following extracts from a recent media release by the Medical Association for the Prevention of War provide graphic evidence of the very real concerns about uranium and the nuclear industry. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Radioactive waste from nuclear reactors contains several hundred elements, many of which remain radioactive for hundreds, and some for thousands, of years. Plutonium is so toxic that hypothetically half a kilogram if adequately distributed, could initiate lung cancer in 5.6 billion human beings. Its half life is 24,400 years and it only requires 5 kilos to manufacture a nuclear weapon. Each thousand megawatt reactor manufactures 200 kilos of plutonium per year.

Strontium 90, a calcium analogue with a radioactive life of 600 years causes bone cancer or leukaemia. Caesium 137, a potassium analogue, also dangerous for 600 years causes muscle sarcomas. Many isotopes, including radioactive iodine which causes thyroid cancer, strontium 90, caesium 137, plutonium and many others are concentrated at each step of the food chain. Furthermore they are tasteless, odourless and invisible, so contaminated food is not detectable by human senses.

The irony of this sad tale is that the nuclear industry often attempts to justify its existence by referring to the use of medical isotopes to treat the very cancers caused by these radioactive elements. Perhaps we should be looking at preventive medicine, as MAPWA states:

We spend hundreds of millions of dollars attempting to cure cancer and/or prevent it. On the other hand, mining companies wish to make money by exporting the element which can increase the incidence of these diseases. Doctors know that the most important principle of preventive medicine is that if a disease is incurable the only recourse is prevention.

There has also been a great deal of work done in Australia and in other parts of the world on the possibility of using cyclotrons for the relatively small amount of nuclear material that is used in diagnostic medicine in Australia. Therefore, the actual amount of nuclear waste that we create in Australia could be very much reduced without the need for nuclear reactors.

PARA.TAB: These environmental health problems are not theoretical. There are many examples around the world of long term or sudden exposure to uranium tailings, radioactive waste or radioactive fallout having caused substantial community health problems. While the thousands of deaths and genetic mutations in Chernobyl are probably the most recent high profile example, there are many others around the world. In the western United States there has been an unusually high incidence of birth defects among babies born to Navaho Indians, due to the proximity of the Navaho nation to more than 350 abandoned open-cut uranium mines.

Given the history of accidents and problems at the ANSTO facility at Lucas Heights, it seems ludicrous to consider adding to the risk by transporting nuclear waste from St Marys, or any other site in Australia, to Lucas Heights for storage for an indeterminate period while it is processed and then transported to Woomera or other waste storage sites. The problems at Lucas Heights are well documented. In July 1990, for example, there was an extensive article in the Bulletin entitled `How safe is the old lady of Lucas Heights?' In this article, senior engineers expressed concern about the safety of the HIFAR facility. Other reports in 1990 highlighted serious concerns about health problems linked to uranium dust. In 1993, the Sutherland Shire Council, which is responsible for the region around the Lucas Heights facility, claimed that the people living in the vicinity of the nuclear facility are at a significantly higher risk than had previously been admitted.

The history of radioactive waste management in Australia is also a woeful tale of incompetence. For years, radioactive waste has been created with no thought to its eventual disposal and, indeed, in the full knowledge that no disposal method exists. That the Commonwealth government now wants to reward some of the organisations which have caused this problem with immunity from state and territory laws is hard to credit. Organisations such as ADI have been shown to be reckless in their creation of radioactive waste in the past. To make them less accountable for that radioactive waste is unacceptable.

This proposal by the government fits well with the sorry state of radioactive waste management in this country. Currently ANSTO is trying to deal with its stockpile of 1,600 spent nuclear fuel rods. Its solution up to this point has been to send them on a hazardous sea voyage across the Pacific Ocean and dump them in the United States. This is a reckless option and one which the 1993 Research Reactor Review described as `morally dubious'. It may also be impossible. The spent fuel would, under the ANSTO proposal, go to the Savannah River site in South Carolina, yet recently a US court placed a permanent injunction against such shipments. While the US government will appeal this decision, it may be too late for ANSTO, which needs to make a shipment of spent fuel by 1995.

The government is also trying to find a site for a national low and intermediate level waste dump. Again, it is a flawed proposal, which basically would involve dumping radioactive waste out of sight and then, hopefully, out of mind. The national dump would be a shallow trench in an arid area—a method which is environmentally unacceptable. It is also politically problematic. The government hopes that by dumping the waste in a remote area people will simply forget it exists, leaving ANSTO free to continue creating radioactive waste. It is not a solution to the problem; it is simply an attempt to deny that the problem exists.

The granting of immunity from state and territory laws to these radioactive waste creating organisations is just another example of the way in which governments seek to shield the nuclear industry and its related organisations from proper public scrutiny and accountability. No other industry has enjoyed such protection and favour, not only in Australia but also internationally. I would remind senators that it was only in 1987 that the Atomic Energy Act 1953 and its draconian security provisions were repealed.

The current federal government, whilst repealing that act, has still allowed ANSTO unacceptable freedom from even the most basic accountability. Currently, ANSTO is subject only to Commonwealth legislation as a result of the 1992 ANSTO Amendment Act. This is of great concern, given that existing legislation relating to ANSTO is so deficient. There is no legislation, for example, that covers discharges from ANSTO's HIFAR reactor. This reactor is located in a residential area in Sydney's south and releases large amounts of certain radioactive isotopes. Its discharges of radioactive iodine 131, for example, are 20 times higher than the massive Sellafield reprocessing facility in the United Kingdom.
The ludicrous nature of this immunity from scrutiny is highlighted in a report for the Sutherland Shire Council by T. F. Robertson, a Sydney lawyer. Mr Robertson states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the extraordinary outcome is that Australia's most hazardous facility
* does not have an effective regulator
* is not required to comply with any occupational, public health or environmental laws or standards
* cannot be prosecuted for breaching standards or operational conditions, even if it does so deliberately
* cannot be restrained from conducting unsafe or polluting activities, and
* is not obliged to compensate the off-site victims of accidental discharges of radiation nor to remediate the environment.
Unlike every other OECD nation and contrary to its international obligations, Australia does not regulate its nuclear facilities. ANSTO regulates itself. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who do you say should regulate it?

—Senator Hill asked who I think should regulate it. I will mention this as I go further. The evidence of proper consultation with the community, environmental groups and local governments has, not surprisingly, been poor. Specifically in relation to the proposal that is the subject of the regulations we are discussing here today, I am aware that the Sutherland shire was advised, not consulted, on the same day that these regulations were tabled in this parliament. Government advisers have assured me that there will be consultation with environmental groups, but there seems to be little evidence of this. Even if that consultation takes place, it will be too late. Consultation should take place before legislation and regulations are drafted, not after they are tabled in this place.

PARA.TAB: There have been concerns expressed about the independence of the Nuclear Safety Bureau, which is given the responsibility of monitoring the activities of ANSTO. These concerns have been partly addressed by merging the Nuclear Safety Bureau with the Australian Radiation Laboratories to form the Australian Institute of Radiation Protection, which is under the control of the minister for health, Dr Lawrence. Unfortunately, there is still a conflict of interest here as the health department has an involvement in nuclear medicine. In addition, the AIRP is still largely staffed by ANSTO personnel or ex-ANSTO personnel. I would like to know why the government does not establish a truly independent monitoring body, with independent nuclear scientists, under the control of the environment minister.

The federal government's response to the appalling problems associated with ANSTO and the inability to properly handle nuclear waste has been to extend the immunity referred to earlier, which ANSTO enjoys, to other organisations, spreading the cloak of secrecy and protection. Such immunity should not be granted to any organisation. It runs completely counter to the principles of open, democratic government and the right of citizens to hold government instrumentalities accountable for their actions.

Thus, organisations such as ADI have got themselves into a situation where they have created radioactive waste with which they are unable to deal. To get them off the hook—that is what the government is trying to do—the federal government is prepared to rely on such anti-democratic legislation as the 1992 ANSTO Amendment Act. The question must be asked: why does this government go to such lengths to protect the nuclear industry and its cohorts? If we look purely at the economics of this industry, which is all the government ever does, we see that the Australian taxpayer has invested the 1991 dollar equivalent of $2.5 billion in the nuclear industry since the 1960s and received the extraordinary return on that investment of approximately $110 million. What a wonderful investment! One can only ask why the government will not implement the only real solution to Australia's current radioactive waste crisis: stopping it being created in the first place.

In relation to the proposal that is the subject of these regulations, I would propose that there be a comprehensive environmental impact assessment process that incorporates proper rather than tokenistic public consultation. I am aware that the government has expressed concern that the disallowance of this motion will result in the waste being left at St Marys but I feel that if proper consultation had taken place on this issue before the regulations were finalised some positive options could have been examined. There are people working in the environment movement and in academic circles who have extensive knowledge of the nuclear industry and the options for nuclear waste storage. We do not have to rely entirely on ANSTO for advice in this regard.

I understand that this proposal for an environmental impact statement and public consultation on storage options is acceptable to the Sutherland Shire Council and to environmental groups such as Friends of the Earth and Greenpeace which have been actively involved in this issue and which have considerable expertise in these issues. I am sure that the government of the state of New South Wales would also welcome the opportunity to have proper input to a process such as this, given the concerns that it has expressed in the past. I trust that the Senate will give this disallowance motion serious consideration. It is not a move that the Greens have taken lightly. We are concerned about the whole issue of nuclear waste disposal and feel that this regulation is a good example of the problems that we will continue to have to face unless the issue is seriously addressed in this parliament and in the broader community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the Australian Democrats have pleasure in supporting Senator Margetts's motion to disallow the ANSTO regulations, and for very much the same reasons as those outlined by Senator Margetts. We have been concerned for very many years about the risks posed by radioactivity to workers and to the general community, and we have taken a position of opposition to both the military and civil use of nuclear power.

PARA.TAB: We also take the position that any country responsible for the manufacture of chemical or radioactive waste is also responsible for its safe handling, storage and disposal. This waste having been generated here, it poses a problem for Australia and we should not seek to shift that problem to another country.

Given that, and despite the fact that the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor has been there for a long time, we have not yet come up with a permanent repository for radioactive waste. The processing which is anticipated to take place at the Lucas Heights site is really only a temporary measure while we consider what to do with this material in a permanent way. We are concerned that here we have a potentially dangerous material, about which we should have decided what to do long before this. But we have procrastinated and have not yet come up with a permanent solution.

We are also concerned about the matter alluded to by Senator Margetts, that the law, as amended in relation to ANSTO, absolves ANSTO from the state environmental protection laws. For that reason, if for no other, we would expect the opposition to also support this disallowance motion. If anything, the opposition has been very vigorous in its defence of states rights. Although it did not support us at the time of the passage of this legislation, I hope it will see the error of its ways and support this disallowance motion on the grounds that ANSTO is simply riding roughshod over state protection laws.

The particular amendment, which was passed in 1992, provides that, subject to subsection 4, the law to which it applies does not apply and can never be taken to have applied in relation to ANSTO, its property, its transactions or anything done by or on behalf of that organisation.

As Senator Margetts pointed out, in its place we have a totally inadequate and rather internal type of supervision and regulation which is effectively no regulation at all. It is certainly not the independent regulation to which most OECD countries would adhere and which any reasonable person would regard as sensible, given the dangerous nature of many of the radioactive materials involved.

The amounts of radioactivity involved here are really relatively small. I understand that the amounts are about seven and a half grams of radium 226, one and a half grams of americium 241, only a very small amount of strontium-cobalt, some transuranics and some carbon 14. The question is not the amount of radioactivity but the principle involved. While there is a code of practice in place for safe transportation of radioactive substances, the treatment of these materials, which is supposed to occur when they get to Lucas Heights, is not covered by a set of procedures which have been subject to close scrutiny. The proponents have outlined how they propose to deal with these things but that is not the same as having a regulation in place which lays down the rules by which that handling and treatment will be conducted.

The government of New South Wales—a Liberal government—had objected most vigorously at the time of the passage of the amendments, which effectively removed the rights of planning legislation and environmental protection legislation in New South Wales to carry out a supervisory role with respect to ANSTO. Again, for that reason alone, the opposition should join with us on this disallowance motion. Moreover, as Senator Margetts has already pointed out, the Sutherland Shire Council has very vigorously opposed the shifting of these radioactive wastes.

Again, if local citizens are to have any influence at all in this chamber, then the vigorous objections of citizens both to the continuation of the operation of the reactor—it is 30 years old and it has been some 40 years since its planning—and to the movement of this radioactive material, which in the absence of a permanent repository might remain at the Lucas Heights site, should be taken seriously and we should disallow this particular regulation.

The operation of the New South Wales law had imposed certain conditions prior to 1992. Judgments had been given in favour of the Sutherland Shire Council prior to that time, and those legal judgments are, of course, still in place. But the passage of the amendments effectively took away any rights which the people of New South Wales could use, through either their state or local governments, with respect to their perceived exposure to danger.

It is for those reasons that we strongly support this disallowance motion. In doing so, we enjoin the government most strongly to move forward and complete the process of determining a permanent repository site and exactly the conditions under which that repository will be run, and to set up a properly independent authority so that the public can be satisfied that those conditions are adhered to with proper sanctions, are transparent with public input and are removed as far as possible from a close association with ANSTO.

Briefly on the question of a permanent repository, again Senator Margetts has drawn attention to the Woomera site in South Australia. We have seen just in the last couple of years Lake Torrens, to the north of Spencer Gulf, filled with water for the first time since white settlement. We have seen for several years a very significant weather shift in South Australia in which the rains have come extremely late in the year and have extended through Christmas time. That has been related to weather coming from the Kimberleys across central Australia and depositing rain in the early summer in South Australia.

It is true that Woomera is, and has been since we have known Woomera, an arid site of very little use in a conventional exploitative sense of land use. However, given the sorts of weather changes which those who are looking at the greenhouse effect are talking about, again I ask the government to consider when it is thinking about a site the fact that in a very short order in terms of human history, and given the length of time these radioactive materials remain active—I have drawn attention to the fact that one of the radioactive products involved in this shift is radium with a half life of 1,600 years—and the significance of greenhouse weather shifts, it may well be that Woomera will become the breadbasket of Australia within the next few hundred years with a very significant change in agricultural practices. We should not be precluding alternative uses of land which we now regard as arid and fairly useless and be closing off options for future generations by making them the site of radioactive dumps. We should be taking into account the need for future generations to have those options left available to them.

One of the concerns that I have in looking at a possible site for putting radioactive wastes is that there is an assumption implicit in the criteria which are laid down that what we observe now and what we have observed over the last 200 years will be the situation for the next 200 years and another 200 years after that. That assumption is patently false and we should not be closing off options for future generations by denying the ability to use sites for alternative purposes should there be a significant change in weather patterns. I simply put that to the government to take into account in considering a permanent repository. The shifting of material from St Marys to Lucas Heights is really a much narrower consideration and we have considerable pleasure in supporting Senator Margetts's motion to disallow this regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion that certain regulations under the ANSTO Act should be disallowed. It is an important matter because it concerns the passage and storage of low level nuclear waste—waste that, we understand, is currently being stored at the ADI premises at St Marys in the western suburbs of Sydney.

PARA.TAB: Section 5 of the ANSTO Act sets out the functions of ANSTO. Those functions include conditioning, managing and storing radioactive materials and radioactive waste arising from a number of different sources but including the activities of other persons who are specified in the regulations. I understand that what the government wants to do is provide ANSTO expertise to put this material that is currently held at St Marys—material which, I think, is technically owned by ADI, although there may be some question about that—into a safe form for transport and then to transport it to what the government is providing as temporary storage at Woomera in South Australia. In order to do that, the government has made this regulation under the provision that I have just mentioned in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of paragraph 5(1)(ba) of the Act—
which is the provision that I have just paraphrased—
the following persons are specified under subparagraph 5(1)(ba)(iv) of the Act:
(a) the Commonwealth;
(b) Australian Defence Industries Limited;
(c) Australian Radiation Laboratory (formerly known as Commonwealth Radium Laboratory, Commonwealth X-Ray and Radium Laboratory, Commonwealth Radiation Laboratory).

So what the government has sought to give ANSTO under this regulation is the very wide power to deal further with nuclear waste in Australia, waste that has been created by the Commonwealth, by ADI or by the Australian Radiation Laboratory.

PARA.TAB: I have listened to the contributions of the Greens and the Australian Democrats and it seems to me that the position of the coalition is a little different from theirs. Basically it seemed to me that Senator Margetts for the Greens was really attacking—I hope I am interpreting this correctly—the nuclear science facility at Lucas Heights and questioning whether the regulatory authority is sufficiently independent and sufficiently adequate to safeguard the public interest. Senator Coulter for the Democrats seemed to be arguing that the material currently at St Marys should not be transported to Woomera and put to us that Woomera some 100 years hence may well have a more valuable function than storage of nuclear waste. That might be so.

We support the nuclear science facility. We believe that it brings benefits to Australia and the Australian people. Although Senator Margetts said that preventive medicine might be more useful to the community, we nevertheless believe that nuclear medicine has served the best interests of the community and continues to do so; that this site helps produce the material that is necessary; and the science that is carried on there is beneficial to Australian interests in many different ways. But this really is not a debate about the nuclear science facility that Australia has, nor is it a debate about the effectiveness of the regulatory authority. This is a debate about ANSTO being empowered to deal further with waste that has been produced by various nuclear facilities in this country or waste that has been brought into this country and utilised in the defence industry or in other areas of science.

It seems to us that the nuclear waste that is currently stored at St Marys in the western suburbs of Sydney should be moved. It does not seem to us to be a suitable repository for that type of material. We are particularly disappointed that the government does not seem to have moved any further, despite its promises to provide in this country a permanent repository for this waste or the low level waste which is produced from the Lucas Heights facility and which has been stored there. We think that that is an equally inappropriate place in the southern suburbs of Sydney for the storage of low-level nuclear waste.

We have therefore been forced to accept the reality that, as a balance of choice, it would be better if this material was temporarily stored at Woomera rather than in the suburbs of Sydney. We were unhappy that the government failed to enter into any form of reasonable consultative process with the people of South Australia in that decision, but nevertheless, as I said, we recognise that it would be better on a temporary basis that the waste be stored there than in the suburbs of Sydney.

We have been a little shy of giving any greater level of support for that because in many ways we think it is enabling the government to further avoid its responsibility to provide a permanent repository. We would be somewhat concerned that this short-term storage may well turn out to be medium-term storage, if not long-term storage, and we would like to find ways in which we could further lever the government to meet the commitment that it has made earlier. But we do not think that this is the occasion to do so.

Therefore, if in fact the regulation that the government had made had been limited to enable ANSTO personnel to make safe this material for transport and to enable them to transport it to this temporary facility at Woomera, then we would be prepared to support the regulation. We have said that to the government and I last said it to Senator Schacht, who seemed to have the conduct of the matter, a matter of only some hours ago.

We have been telling the government for some time that its regulation, in our view, goes far beyond what it claims to be the purpose of that regulation. As I have said, it includes waste produced by the Commonwealth, by ADI, which the government says is the purpose, also by the Australian Radiation Laboratory. It in no way limits what ANSTO personnel might do with its material. There is concern in New South Wales that as a matter of convenience the material will be simply transferred to Lucas Heights. The government has said that it might be that some of the material will need to be transferred to Lucas Heights to be made safe for transport.

I have trouble with the logic of that. If it is unsafe to be transported out of Sydney, I cannot quite see how it is safe to be transported across Sydney. Nevertheless, the government has not gone further in its submissions to us, other than to say that it might be necessary to use facilities at Lucas Heights to help make safe facilities that in turn cannot be transported to the St Marys site.

If we could see that the government had demonstrated good faith in this area and had kept its promises over the years, we might be more prepared to accept what the government says is its intentions in this matter. But it does not have a good record in this regard. It is simply asking us to give it much greater discretion in dealing with this waste than is necessary to achieve the objective that it claims, and we are not prepared to agree to that.

I reiterate that if the government is prepared to put its regulation in a form that is sufficient to allow it to make safe this material and to transport it to Woomera, then we will agree to it. As I said to Senator Schacht earlier today, if as a result this regulation is disallowed and there needs to be an appropriate resolution under the Acts Interpretation Act to rescind the resolution that is passed to enable a new regulation to be put down in more limited terms, then we will facilitate that as well.

If the government, when its scientists and technicians have access to the material at ADI, finds that in fact it does need to be transported to Lucas Heights, and the government puts a substantive case to that effect to the parliament, then we will look sympathetically upon that as well. As I have said, we want to get the material out of St Marys. I do not know why the government has not been prepared to meet the reasonable requirements that we have asked for.

The government should be aware that what it is proposing is causing concern in the suburbs of Sydney. There is concern around Lucas Heights, there has been concern around St Marys, and I do not know why the government was not prepared to come in here today with a form of regulation that would achieve what it wanted without raising the extra concerns that I have mentioned. Perhaps the minister will explain the position when he responds.

As things stand at the moment, on the basis of the material that I have read and the arguments that I have listened to, I will on behalf of the coalition support the motion to rescind this regulation. But, as I have said, and I stress, simply not in a way that is intended to make difficult the responsibility of the government to move this material but in a way that would responsibly meet our wider responsibility to the community at large and facilitate the removal of this waste to Woomera.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Other speakers, in their introductory comments, have described the circumstances that lead us to this situation. Let me, as briefly as possible, seek to address why these regulations have been brought in, their purpose and intention, and those steps which the Commonwealth is prepared to take to seek to ensure that they are acceptable to the majority of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The ANSTO Act, under which these regulations have been made, provides that the functions of ANSTO include conditioning, managing and storing radioactive materials and radioactive waste, arising either from activities in which ANSTO is involved or from the activities of persons who are specified in regulations. That is the form of the act and the requirement that these regulations need to meet. The intent of this regulation, which came into effect in July, is to permit ANSTO to undertake the work of conditioning a small quantity of radioactive wastes presently stored at the site of the former St Marys munitions factory in western Sydney.

Some detailed description of it has been given by other senators; I will not repeat all that, but let me go to it in this abbreviated way. The waste, which is approximately 10 cubic metres in volume, arises from various past activities of the Commonwealth and is managed by Australian Defence Industries on behalf of the Department of Defence. The wastes need to be moved to allow ADI to clear and redevelop the site as it proposes to consolidate its operations elsewhere.

About half the waste is classified as category A or B; that is, a low level of radioactivity and includes items such as electronic valves, luminous watches and luminous compasses. The remainder is classified as category S, or intermediate level waste, and it is this which requires conditioning. The conditioning will immobilise the wastes to make them safer for transportation.

As we all know, ANSTO is the Commonwealth specialist nuclear technology arm and is the appropriate Australian body to undertake the conditioning. ANSTO advises that its current intention is to do all the conditioning at St Marys and that it is highly unlikely that it will be necessary to bring any items of the waste to the ANSTO site at Lucas Heights. It is not possible, while the material is still sealed, to be absolutely certain about that; we need to open it up, under these regulations, before we can be absolutely certain—but that is the intention and the expectation.

It seems inconceivable that anyone could be opposed to the basic intent of the regulation—I understand that Senator Hill said that he is not—which allows ANSTO to make radioactive wastes safer so that they can be moved from an area which is to be redeveloped as a housing site. It is inconceivable that the purpose can be under challenge.

Let us look at what I understand to be—and from the debate appears to be confirmed—the main concerns with the regulation: firstly, it might give ANSTO and the Commonwealth wider powers than simply to condition the St Marys waste, that is, it could apply to all Commonwealth wastes indefinitely; secondly, the concern by the local Sutherland council that some material may have to be brought to Lucas Heights; and, thirdly, an allegation that there has been a lack of consultation in the treatment of this matter.

I will deal with each of these in turn. One is the breadth of the powers. I think I picked up Senator Hill's point correctly, which is additional to that which I previously understood; a concern about the inclusion of the Australian Radiation Laboratory under this heading. I understand that it is responsible for a small amount of this waste and that therefore it needs to be included. That is my advice.

The government and I accept that, in its current form, the regulation could be applied to other Commonwealth waste. That was not its intention on introduction and it is not our intention now, but as it currently stands it could so be interpreted and therefore used in that way.

As a consequence of that, we have indicated to interested senators—I understand to Green senators and coalition representatives—that we are prepared to introduce an amended regulation with a sunset clause of 31 December 1995. This would allow sufficient time to ensure that the work on the St Marys wastes could be completed while providing a genuine curb on the regulation being used for any other purpose.

It has been suggested that we could do this by a regulation specifying this particular waste. But the clear advice to the government from the Attorney-General's Department is that such a specification would have no legal meaning. The act requires the regulation to specify only the persons on whose behalf the ANSTO is conditioning the waste.

The Attorney-General's Department continues to advise that the present form of the regulations is correct given the requirements of the act. Separate regulations would be needed if ANSTO were to undertake conditioning work on behalf of other legal entities, such as Commonwealth statutory authorities or state government bodies.

Hence, the only other Commonwealth waste to which these regulations could possibly be applied in the future is some waste administered by the Department of Defence, of which there is about 50 cubic metres, I am told. It may be that some of this waste will need conditioning for transfer to the permanent low level repository when that is established. But that is unlikely to be necessary before the end of 1995. If it is ultimately necessary to move that waste, a new regulation would be brought forward after 1995. The sunset clause would come to an end and any new material needed to be dealt with would be dealt with under some such legislation; that is, within the constraints of the legislation, an effective guarantee that this regulation will not be used beyond the purposes for which it is intended, although we accept that the drafting, as it currently stands, could be better and we will move to clarify it.

But we do not have the capacity to amend the regulation. We all know the procedural constraints on the Senate on amending a regulation in the way proposed, but we give a guarantee that we will, as soon as possible, come back with such a regulation. I understand that 7 November will be the first practicable day on which we can introduce such a regulation and we undertake to do so.

The second concern is the possibility that the material might come to Lucas Heights. I understand that this concern was raised by the Sutherland council in whose area the Lucas Heights facility is sited. I have already pointed out that the advice from ANSTO is that it intends to do all the conditioning at St Marys and that it is highly unlikely that it will be necessary to bring any items of the waste to the ANSTO site at Lucas Heights.

However, it is remotely possible that when ANSTO starts treating the waste some items may require specialised facilities not available at St Marys. In this unlikely event, the volume to be moved would be only about two 200 litre drums. The Environmental Protection Authority—that is, the Commonwealth EPA—and all relevant state and local government authorities would be kept informed and transport procedures would have to meet the Australian code of practice for the safe transport of radioactive substances.

Importantly, there is no intention that any such waste would be stored at Lucas Heights, even on an interim basis. The waste packages would be held at Lucas Heights only for the minimum time required for safe conditioning. I can understand the—

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't follow the logic. I can't see how it would be safe to move it across Sydney but not out of Sydney.

—Senator Hill's logic, as good as it is, would also tell him that if it cannot be dealt with at St Marys, it needs to be moved somewhere where it can be dealt with and it would be transferred as safely as possible to Lucas Heights and prepared.
—That is going to give great confidence to the people of Sydney.
—But the alternative is not to move it. There is no third option. That is the logic. It is exhaustible. We move it or we do not.
—Why not find out whether it is safe?
—We cannot start to condition it until the regulation is passed.
—I accept that you could have a regulation that gives you power.
—That is what this does.
—You want to do both. You want to have the right to move it to Lucas Heights when you don't know whether you need to move it to Lucas Heights.
—You have criteria for transport but not for treatment. That is another big loophole.

—I cannot see how the circumstance is going to be enhanced, in terms of dealing with the problem senators have, by repealing this regulation. I cannot see that what they are envisaging is not somehow going to be achieved by the point they are making. It is very understandable—this is an issue about which people have concerns. That is a very human thing. There are people opposed to everything related to the nuclear industry and some who are not, but who are reasonably concerned to ensure that the provisions of any particular proposal are seriously and closely considered. All that is perfectly understandable.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the situation we have here. There is some waste, which was produced years ago, which needs to be treated at the appropriate and safest facilities. The capacity to do that resides with the people at Lucas Heights. To oppose this regulation because there is a remote chance that some waste may have to go to the Lucas Heights facility really means that that is a determination that it is not suitable for Lucas Heights—and it should stay in St Marys. It is not going to disappear. It is not a regulation to give us the magic capacity to make it disappear overnight. It is saying, `Do not send it to Lucas Heights. Please keep it in St Marys.' It is also saying, `Do not apply the appropriate methods for the safe treatment of this radioactive waste—keep it in its current condition.' Those seem to me to be flawed proposals. There is no perfect proposal for dealing with this. We have a series of options. We have to choose which is the best of the various alternatives before us.

I will deal briefly with the question of consultation. I am not saying that it is unimportant, but it does not go to the core of why people are voting for or against this proposal, although it may influence the degree of their concern. My advice—I have not been involved in any of the consultations directly—is that there has been significant consultation with groups affected by the transfer of the waste at St Marys: the various environmental authorities, representatives at Woomera and various other relevant community and interest groups. There are further consultations under way. Final transport and storage arrangements will require the approval of the Commonwealth EPA.

What we have to say, rather than establishing that this regulation does not create the perfect circumstance, is, `What happens if we oppose it? What happens if this motion is carried?' What should be done then with any waste that does need the specialised facilities at Lucas Heights? What are the alternatives? They are not limitless. We can leave it at St Marys forever. We can transport it to Woomera in an untreated condition, but there will be no facilities there to treat it properly. We can condition it at St Marys without the proper equipment or pay significant extra costs to bring in a foreign organisation to undertake the conditioning. Just because this act precludes ANSTO from doing it, it does not preclude somebody else from doing it. There are skilled international companies, I am advised, which have a capacity comparable with ANSTO. We could get them to come in and do it; it just costs a lot of money and gets an American to do it, instead of the appropriate Australian authorities. That would be a very strange outcome to be pursuing—a very perverse outcome.

If the regulation is disallowed, we will have the perverse result that, in response to genuinely held environmental concerns, the waste at St Marys would be kept less safe, allegedly in the name of protecting the public. What the government wants to do is allow ANSTO to have the authority to condition the St Marys waste. We have taken all reasonable steps to limit the regulation to this purpose. Once we have given the guarantee, we accept that although our intention has always been that limited intent, the regulation is open to wider interpretation. That was not our intention; and we will correct it as I have indicated and will reiterate.

I am advised that Senator Schacht wrote to Senator Hill recently giving various assurances about consultation and limiting the effect of the regulation. I have seen the correspondence between Senator Schacht and Senator Hill. I do not think there is any controversy about the fact that it took place. On behalf of the government, I reiterate the commitment that if this disallowance motion is rejected, the government will introduce on the first practicable day, which I am informed is 7 November, a regulation incorporating a sunset clause of 31 December 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you say that again?

—If the disallowance motion is defeated, that is, if the regulation stands, we will introduce a regulation incorporating a sunset clause so that the concern that the regulation might be used to deal with some other waste is overcome. That clause would effectively prevent any of the other waste that could conceivably be covered by these regulations from being handled. It would mean that if any of the other waste about which senators are concerned was to be dealt with by ANSTO, there would need to be another regulation.

PARA.TAB: My understanding and recollection from a previous existence as Manager of Government Business is that, if the disallowance motion is passed, an amended regulation could not be introduced for another six months and, therefore, no work could be undertaken on treating the waste for that period, unless we brought in somebody other than ANSTO to do it—somebody from overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, by leave of the Senate you can do it. If it is sufficiently different you can do it. There is no reason why you couldn't.
—The other thing is that we said we would agree to a rescission motion. So that's no problem.
—No-one has said that to me before.

PARA.TAB: That the Declaration made by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on 10 July 1994, under subsection 10(1) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, relating to Hindmarsh Island, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I first spoke on this matter on 6 June when the Senate had tabled the preceding declaration, which was a one-month temporary declaration, by the same minister on the same tropic. My speech is in the Senate Hansard and has been referred to by a number of people who have been interested in this matter ever since.

PARA.TAB: On 11 June I made a submission to the minister's appointed person to conduct an inquiry, Professor Cheryl Saunders, who received my submission along with very many from others in South Australia. Her report was given to the minister, and this led to his making on 9 July a declaration which has the effect of placing a 25-year ban upon the Hindmarsh Island bridge.

It was a bridge that was to be built under agreement between the South Australia government and a major developer of Hindmarsh Island, but to advantage not only that development but all the residents of the lower Murray area, and in particular the residents of Hindmarsh Island. There is a ferry that operates from Goolwa on the mainland across the 100 metres or so to a causeway on the island. This ferry has operated for decades. It is costing the South Australian taxpayer a considerable amount of money. In making the decision to build the bridge to replace the ferry, the South Australian government has noted the savings that would flow in terms of maintenance and operational costs.

By having a bridge instead of a ferry we have the advantage of a permanent access—with no delays—to move from the island to the mainland. At some times of the day in summer there are delays of at least half an hour, sometimes one hour, to get on board the ferry because so many people want to go to

SPEECH.PARA: or fro at the one time. The residents on the island are concerned to have access to hospital treatment in an emergency, and they also want the normal facility of easy access from their homes to the rest of the region—indeed to the city of Adelaide—without this impediment of delay.

PARA.TAB: The bridge is of vital importance to the developer of a marina and to the residents who have already taken allotments in a real estate development around the marina. They have a legitimate interest to protect. Not only is the facility of direct benefit to them, but the bridge was promised. It was not just a promise by the South Australian government; a contract to build the bridge was fully entered into by the South Australia government, and many people based investment decisions on the fact that such a bridge would be built. There are 800 allotments for 800 families who already have acted on the basis of that expectation. Many more families are long time residents of Hindmarsh Island.

On 6 June in the Senate I mentioned that I am broadly familiar with this region. It is not only part of the electorate that I have represented for the last 17 years, but it is also an area that I have visited since I was a boy. I regularly sail in the lower Murray areas with my family, and I walk in the Coorong National Park. To get to the national park I have to go from Goolwa to Hindmarsh Island and sail through the lock in the barrage and down through to the Murray mouth and around to Tauwitchere and into the Coorong.

I go there because I love the area. I love the birds and the natural state of the area, which in the Coorong National Park is largely unspoiled. The people of Hindmarsh Island and the developer want to keep it that way. In fact, it is a legally binding commitment that in any developments on the island measures will be taken to preserve every element of the natural heritage.

This was an extraordinary intervention by the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Affairs, Mr Tickner to ban the bridge on the basis of a report by Professor Saunders. That report includes material which cannot be disclosed publicly. Any argument or evidence that is put forward in the report is too flimsy for a decision by any of us in the Senate, let alone by the Commonwealth minister who is required to be accountable to this Parliament and to the Australian public for the decisions that are made.

I will argue four propositions. Firstly, I believe that the Senate should disallow this declaration by the minister so as to ensure justice for all Australians. Secondly, I believe that the declaration should be disallowed by the Senate to ensure credibility of Aboriginal claims. I will explain why I do not believe that the basis for this declaration, in so far as it relates to Aboriginal beliefs or concerns, is sufficiently sound to be credible.

Thirdly, I will argue that all governments should be accountable. They cannot make decisions affecting thousands of people—and, by implication, all Australians—without accountability, without an explanation that adds up to everybody concerned. I have a strong, well established record of direct concern for the natural environment and direct concern for Aboriginal issues, Aboriginal concerns and Aboriginal priorities. I believe that the lack of credibility for the Aboriginal issues involved in this matter reflects badly, and indeed reflects discredit, upon the whole process that this parliament wants to establish for the genuine protection of Aboriginal beliefs and Aboriginal sites. If we allow the currency to be debased in this way, we are putting in jeopardy the valuable principles of the protection of Aboriginal heritage where it can genuinely and credibly be attested to.

Fourthly, I believe that the Senate should disallow this declaration to ensure that there are fair foundations for development and enterprise in Australia. Developers and investors need to know with assurance from the earliest stages of any proposal that there is a legal certainty on which they can act and so get on with their development efficiently and effectively and meet all of the requirements of environment impact statements and the like that are required in the preliminary stage. In this case full approval for this development, which included the bridge, was given in April 1990—four and a half years ago—and the company involved has a $15 million debt. It is a $175 million development which has been reversed or stopped by the declaration of a Commonwealth minister on the basis of very flimsy evidence to which I will now refer.

With regard to the first proposition, the Senate should disallow this declaration on the basis of justice for all Australians, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, and equally for all the residents in this part of South Australia. The Fleurieu Regional Development Corporation commissioned an economic study related to the bridge, and this professional report has concluded that the banning of the bridge will mean the loss of 1200 new jobs and an economic loss of $175 million to the region.

It is therefore understandable that hundreds of local people rallied in Goolwa and demonstrated that they wanted the bridge to go ahead. Not only have there been many articles, statements and newsletters issued by those supporting the bridge, but also weekly meetings on Hindmarsh Island, one of which I have addressed. I can inform the Senate of the genuine concerns of these ordinary Australians. Certainly, they have a direct personal interest in the outcome, but we ought to take that fairly into account and give them justice.

The South Australian government was elected to redress the debts and problems of the state and, with a strong endorsement by the people of South Australia for a development program, to bring prosperity back to South Australia. Why should that program of development and prosperity be denied by the intrusion of a Commonwealth minister into the lower Murray? I do not believe there is credibility in the Aboriginal claims. SPEECH.PARA: Aborigines `told how to stop bridge'
Advertiser 16/9/94
By Chief Reporter Colin James

PARA.TAB: The Federal Government advised Aborigines on how to stop the controversial Hindmarsh Island bridge project, the Federal Court has been told.
And the federal Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Mr Tickner, allegedly drafted an order to stop the project before receiving a report on its impact on Aboriginal sacred sites.

A judicial review was told yesterday Mr Tickner authorised the drafting of an order stopping the bridge for 25 years the day before he received the results of an investigation by Victorian legal academic Professor Cheryl Saunders.
The allegations surfaced during the preliminary stages of a legal bid by marina developers Tom and Wendy Chapman to overturn Mr Tickner's decision to stop the $6.4 million bridge.
Mr and Mrs Chapman want the Federal Court to rule that the decision—announced on July 11—was unlawful and a breach of natural justice.
Mr David Meyer, for the Chapmans, introduced yesterday crucial changes to their application for the judicial review after obtaining Federal government papers.

The documents include several ministerial briefings prepared for Mr Tickner, which revealed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission officers in Canberra told Aborigines in April they should provide evidence of the `cultural significance' of sacred sites threatened by the bridge.
The Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee had asked Mr Tickner to use special Commonwealth laws to delay or stop the bridge because it threatened sites of `archaeological significance'.
However, ATSIC told the committee the legislation had not been used to protect a site `primarily of archaeological significance'.
ATSIC said Mr Tickner would be `greatly influenced' by evidence of the `cultural significance' of the sites affected by the bridge, Mr Meyer said.

SPEECH.PARA: `Women's issues'

PARA.TAB: Another briefing document reveals ATSIC also told Mr Tickner any evidence of `past or present cultural associations' would `considerably strengthen' his `position'.
Mr Meyer said Aboriginal women fighting the project provided claims of `women's issues' affected by the project one week after receiving the ATSIC call for cultural information.

`So we have in a ministerial brief, dated April 13, ATSIC reporting to the minister that ATSIC has advised Aboriginal persons that if they provide evidence of cultural matters, that will considerably strengthen his hand and promptly, on April 21, you find an ATSIC brief which, for the first time, raises a significant cultural matter,' he said.
`. . . we say that the totally different tack arose because ATSIC suggested it and you see, a week later, it immediately happens.'

Mr Meyer said one of the `key informants' for Professor Saunders' report, Mrs Doreen Kartinyeri, wrote to Mr Tickner on May 12 and said she had only `recently' discovered the significance of the Hindmarsh Island region to Aboriginal women.

`I have always known about the stories associated with the Raminyeri and Ngarrindjeri women's business but until recently I did not know the exact place that they referred to,' says Mrs Kartinyeri's letter.

Mr Meyer said `women's issues' had not been raised with Mr Tickner's office when an adviser met two Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee representatives, Mr Douglas Milera and Mr George Trevorrow, last December.
The representatives instead had told Mr Tickner's adviser they wanted the bridge project stopped because Aboriginal people did not trust Mr and Mrs Chapman with skeletal remains.
The hearing, before Judge Maurice O'Loughlin, continues today.

SPEECH.PARA: SIGNIFICANT ABORIGINAL AREAS IN THE VICINITY OF GOOLWA AND HINDMARSH (KUMARANGK) ISLAND, SOUTH AUSTRALIA

One further challenge to the characterisation of the bridge as destructive to aboriginal tradition was suggested to me by Lindy Warrell, an anthropologist consulted by Tom and Wendy Chapman. While she said that she had no knowledge of`the women figure legend' she questioned whether the bridge, rather than joining the island and the mainland, did not rather `mediate separateness' by emphasising the fact that they are apart. While the point can be appreciated in logic, she was not able to give me an illustration of the application in the time available in Australian Aboriginal culture. In the circumstances it was impossible to take the point further. The remainder of her views are set out in the second Supplementary Submission from Tom, Wendy and Andrew Chapman and I draw the Minister's attention to them.
I note also the contrasting (but equally tentative) point made by Dr Fergie in the third Appendix to her Report. While the Appendix is confidential this extract may be divorced from its context.

PARA.TAB: A critical point may be that Kumarangk and Mundoo can only go together when they are mediated by the life-supporting waters of the Goolwa Channel. The complex relationship between contingent separation and the togetherness of life and death is achieved by water. The separation of all the major organs in this system is mediated and achieved by water.

Whenever women were called upon to explain what was different about the barrages and the proposed bridge they referred to the water in some way. It occurs to me that it may well be that what the women haven't been able to articulate clearly is that the problem with linking Kumarangk and the mainland together by a bridge is precisely that a bridge goes above the water. It is a shore to shore, direct and permanent link. It would make that link, unlike the barrage or the ferry cable, unmediated by water. It would . . . make the system sterile.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to these two documents. It has become quite clear that the so-called women's issues involving the Ngarrindjeri women were never heard of by state government, by local government or by local residents until April this year—four years after the development was approved by the state government and some years after various Aboriginal heritage matters were put to the South Australian government for exploration, all of which led to a green light from the Aboriginal heritage section of the South Australian government.

PARA.TAB: The main spokesman for the Ngarrindjeri women was a Mrs Doreen Kartinyeri. She wrote to Mr Tickner on 12 May and said that she had only recently discovered the significance of the Hindmarsh Island region to Aboriginal women. She was the chief spokesman for those women. She said:
"I have always known about the stories associated with the Raminyeri and Ngarrindjeri women's business but until recently I did not know the exact place that they referred to . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I commend Mrs Kartinyeri for her honesty. I have no argument with her or her friends. She has been honest. She does not live in the area; she lives in Cape York Peninsula. I do not know of any Ngarrindjeri women, besides her. The Ngarrindjeri men whom I have met in the area do not know of any Ngarrindjeri women still living in the lower Murray.

PARA.TAB: I have yet to hear from anybody as to whether there are more than five Ngarrindjeri women. There are certainly fewer than 35 Ngarrindjeri women because all of the Aboriginal network in South Australia, including the Kauna and other Aboriginal groups in the state, came together in April and May to demonstrate and to lobby. This included people who were not Ngarrindjeri. Out of the group of 35, I do not know whether there are more than five who are left. The one put forward as the spokesman said that she did not know the site was significant to the women's issues.

What are these women's issues? I will try to be guarded because I have not read the secret envelopes. The lower Murray region is quite reasonably seen to represent for some Aboriginal women an analogy—a dreaming—associated with reproduction and the birth of children. It is an important element of life for all communities in all times. We are not aware of the detail of this; but, with regard to a bridge being built between the mainland and one island, which is part of the lower Murray area, reference to Dr Fergie has been made in the public document of Professor Saunders. Dr Fergie is the anthropologist on this issue, appointed this year by the Aboriginal legal rights movement. Professor Saunders said:

SPEECH.PARA: I note also the contrasting (but equally tentative) point made by Dr Fergie in the third Appendix to her Report.
Dr Fergie stated:

Whenever women were called upon to explain what was different about the barrages and the proposed bridge they referred to the water in some way. In occurs to me that it may well be that what the women haven't been able to articulate clearly is that the problem with linking Kumarangk—
that is Hindmarsh Island—
and the mainland together by a bridge is precisely that a bridge goes above—
the word `above' is underlined—
the water. It is a shore to shore, direct and permanent link. It would make that link, unlike the barrage or the ferry cable, unmediated by water. It would . . . make the system sterile.

That is the best account we have as to the reason for blocking the bridge. Because a bridge is unmediated by water, it is somehow offensive to the spiritual significance of the lower Murray region for maybe five women. I respect the spiritual beliefs and views and anything that is dearly held by those five women, but they themselves did not know what the significance of this area was until April this year.

PARA.TAB: When they tried to explain it through their anthropologist to Professor Saunders, they could not articulate it. I do not blame people for not being able to articulate things, but even now it does not make any sense. There is no explanation. No explanation has been given by the minister. No explanation has been given by Professor Saunders. We are putting in jeopardy $175 million worth of development, the direct safety and concerns of the residents of Hindmarsh Island and the concerns of the mayor of Goolwa and all of his councillors, who have been elected by the local people, because a bridge is unmediated by water.

Does it mean that there is some fear amongst the four or five women that there would not be live births or that their spiritual belief would somehow be obstructed or compromised? That is not being put forward. There is no logic in the explanation. If there is logic, please may we all be enlightened. The government is not being accountable and it is a failure of accountability for a minister to stop a bridge on the basis of such a flimsy reference to the spiritual beliefs of some Aboriginal Australians.

I agreed with the minister when he spoke with me personally that we should all have due concern for the spiritual beliefs of all Australians—of course we must. There must be tolerance and acceptance of the freedom of religion. But where it affects other people, there needs to be an explanation.
I quote one of the Ngarrindjeri men who lives in the region and who works for the local council. He is reported as stating:
"I think this will affect the whole of Australia," long-time Goolwa resident and Ngarrindjeri descendent John McHughes said this week.
He was speaking of the decision by Federal Aboriginal Affairs Minister Robert Tickner to stop the Goolwa-Hindmarsh Island Bridge.
Mr McHughes believes he and his family are the only Ngarrindjeri descendents still living in the Goolwa area.
He said he had never heard anything about sacred sites in the vicinity of the proposed Goolwa-Hindmarsh Island Bridge

SPEECH.PARA: The local people who know John hear this and know that he was the man who, working for the local government, drove the bridge piles into the mud for the ferry to operate from each bank. They believe him and they listen to him. They have no acceptance of the credibility of Professor Saunders one-page reference to this or to the secret envelopes that Minister Tickner has not been able to read.

PARA.TAB: One Aboriginal leader in South Australia said that, when the piles were driven for the Goolwa ferry into the bottom of the Murray River, he felt the pain in his stomach. The only Ngarrindjeri man who lives in the area is the fellow who was driving the piles into the bottom of the Murray River. If we are to accept nonsense as the basis for a government decision we will be held accountable by the people who elected us.

We require this Australian government to act with accountability and credibility. If there are any legitimate spiritual beliefs of people anywhere in Australia, by all means let us try to protect them but on the basis of fair dealing and good knowledge. The Adelaide Advertiser in an editorial on 11 July, two days after the minister's decision, said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: But the intervention of the Federal Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Mr Tickner, the reasons for his embargo and its circumstances raise new concerns at once farcical and disturbing.

. . . no sane society can take far-reaching government decisions largely on the basis of sealed evidence which someone simply asserts is in some way sacred or taboo and therefore to remain sealed from discovery.

I have the genuine view that this evidence was contrived to meet the concerns of the environmental lobby which had failed to stop the bridge. It was not known to the South Australian government. This matter, even in its non-explained state, does not exist on any anthropological records anywhere in South Australia. A burden was placed upon a few Aboriginal women to come up with some culturally significant sacred matter that could be used as a basis to help the environmentalists with whom they were working to block the bridge.

PARA.TAB: I do not call into question the bona fides of Mrs Kartinyeri or the other Aboriginal women themselves but I believe that they were used and, even then, when they were used, the explanation does not stack up. The minister, Mr Tickner, in his press release of 10 July said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the reconciliation process is to be meaningful—
he means reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians—a concept, a goal that I strongly support. I say that most sincerely—
it is especially important that the spiritual beliefs of Aboriginal people be accorded no lesser respect than the spiritual beliefs of non Aboriginal Australians.

I say the same to Mr Tickner with regard to the spiritual beliefs of the other residents of the lower Murray region of South Australia. Let us pay equal, fair and just regard to the beliefs, interests and concerns of everybody involved in this area. Where there is no explanation by a tiny minority to the overwhelming majority who want the bridge, let the explanation be all the more carefully and credibly put forward. There has been a complete failure to do so in this regard.

PARA.TAB: I have already discussed with Minister Tickner the need, in order to establish fair foundations for development and enterprise, to amend the current 1984 act so that any concern of this nature is dealt with at the environmental impact stage before major investment takes place with regard to any development anywhere in Australia. I am heartened that Mr Tickner acknowledges that and wants to amend the act to ensure that any such declaration by a minister in this regard is made at an early stage in any development.

But let it be fully understood that in Australia we have a requirement to work according to law. There is a fundamental principle at stake here and that is the need to uphold the certainty of legal approvals. In this case the original full environmental development approval was given by the South Australian government in April 1990, four and a half years ago. Three matters were referred to the Aboriginal heritage branch of the South Australian government. They were dealt with on 8 May 1992, 9 November 1993 and, finally, on 3 May 1994 and they all concluded that the bridge should go ahead.

I note that, so far as South Australia is concerned, there was a tardy four-year process before construction on the bridge commenced. There were two attempts in October last year and in May this year for the contractors to go there and start work. The minister intervened on the second attempt to start work.

I can only appeal to government senators, to the Greens and to the Australian Democrats. I appeal to Senator Coulter from South Australia and to Senator Chamarette to take into account the four principles that I have referred to in arguing that the Senate should now disallow the minister's declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that it is almost ten to seven, with the concurrence of the Senate I propose to call on consideration of government documents.
