SPEECH.PARA: The Industry Commission is reliable and consistent. It can be relied on to consistently argue the same line irrespective of the problems and irrespective of the industry. In this petrol report we have recommendations of widespread deregulation of the petrol industry. Ignoring the fact that petrol industries in all countries are so dominated by a small number of players that virtually every other country in the world has opted for some level of regulation, the Industry Commission has argued that self-regulation and no regulation are the best way to go.

PARA.TAB: The inevitable result of this would be further concentration of distributors and retailers in the ownership of the oil companies, resulting in even less competition and higher prices for rural people. When the Industry Commission itself concedes that its policy recommendations may result in a minority of country residents paying more for petrol, rural Australia should get very worried. I can understand why the government chose to sit on this report for three months, then release a statement which commits itself to none of it, but promises further reviews, inquiries and consultations. What is urgently needed in this country is a competitive wholesale distribution market for petrol. That is the best guarantee that country customers will get lower petrol prices.

The Industry Commission's recommendations will not deliver that and neither will further government procrastination. Only pro-active, pro-competition, pro-consumer policy action will deliver that. As well as failing to address the city/country petrol price disparities, the Industry Commission has failed to address the urgent need for an environmental clean-up within the petroleum industry.

I am pleased that the government has decided on both counts to largely ignore the commission's report, but this leaves us wondering why we bother having an Industry Commission which costs $27 million a year. The Democrats oppose much of the legislative reforms proposed by the commission and urge the government to keep the needs of consumers—especially country consumers—very much in mind when deciding on its final response to the report.

When I was in North Queensland in August, petrol prices in Townsville were 8c a litre higher than those in Brisbane; in Cairns and Mackay, 9c higher; and in Mossman—in far North Queensland—10c higher. That means that the average family in Townsville pays an extra $160 a year to run the family car. High country petrol prices contribute to geographic discrimination, making it more expensive for businesses to operate in country areas.

The Industry Commission attempts to argue that the differential between city and country prices is largely explained by freight costs. However, the commission's own data shows that only about half of the difference in costs between New South Wales and Queensland towns can be explained by freight. The simple fact is that the current petrol pricing system is failing rural people, and this report will do little to improve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we have another one of these wonderful Industry Commission reports that come out from time to time! I will let others outline the problems for consumers and retailers and point out the environmental folly of allowing fluctuations in price that negate any attempt at disincentive or incentive. I will talk about the Industry Commission's approach.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting because, in its report, the Industry Commission starts by outlining a situation where the market is essentially controlled by five companies. This makes it an oligopoly. It also notes that the companies frequently collude with each other—acting as a cartel—and this has been alluded to already by Senator Woodley.

Economic fundamentalists can rant all they want to about government interference, but no real economist worth his or her salt believes that an oligopolistic cartel-dominated market works the way Adam Smith or Ricardo said it was supposed to. Smith and Ricardo said that it did not, and that the result was a form of distortion of the classical market—market failure. When a player or players dominate the market, the principle of normal competitive adjustment cannot function, according to classical economists not tied to an ideology that says that privatisation and lack of control is automatically the solution, regardless of the problem.

Whenever there is an element controlling the market, it does not work in an unbiased way. When government is the controller, there is a distortion of the market introduced by the community as a whole to achieve social goals. Minimal government intervention is anti-trust action—action designed to stop the domination of a market by one player or a few players. The classic example of monopoly dominance, and of trust-busting legislation introduced to stop it, was the case of the Rockefeller oil companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a Trade Practices Act, you know.

—Domination by a cartel or oligopoly also creates a distortion of the market—except that while government, in principle, represents the people, a cartel or oligopoly represents only the interests of certain corporations. Senator Boswell mentioned that we have a Trade Practices Act, but while this cartel is operating so effectively, that act is obviously not operating, is it? Because of its direct dominance of market transaction—its power as a price setter—it can usually introduce greater distortion in a market than all but the most heavily interventionist government.

PARA.TAB: This is the situation that the Industry Commission has outlined as existing—a five member, globally-based oligopoly acting as a cartel and dominating the Australian market. The Industry Commission outlines specific mechanisms where the distortion generates profits for the cartel at the expense of consumers generally, including business consumers; at the expense of rural consumers specifically—as was mentioned by Senator Woodley; at the expense of petrol retailers, both franchisees and independent operators; at the expense of social factors—that is, government attempts to introduce incentives and disincentives environmentally and therefore at the expense of the environment; at the expense of workers and their families; and, through their taxes and business taxes, at the expense of the people of Australia.

For this reason, a number of laws have been enacted in this place—price controls, the site act and the franchise act—designed to assure some measure of justice and some resemblance to the classic market. The oligopoly still significantly distorts the market, as outlined by the Industry Commission.

At this point, the Industry Commission report starts to lose any credibility. The conclusion it draws from this situation is that most regulations should be eliminated. The site act and the franchise act should be repealed, in spite of strong calls by retailers and franchisors to retain them. The Industry Commission argues that since the victims of the cartel remain victims—being inadequately protected—the solution is to eliminate any protection afforded them. I find this astounding. It is one of the reasons that I would fight against having an inquiry referred to the Industry Commission. Its members are doctors who prescribe more leeches for any complaint, including anaemia! They suggest that somehow the anti-trust laws are an impediment to self-regulation and assume that somehow self-regulation would obviously and automatically result in greater justice and less market distortion.

These five big companies are admittedly at their most dangerous when acting in concert as a cartel, but the suggestion is that somehow getting those five big companies together to regulate the market will save things. Somehow, describing a cartel set up to regulate its own market as `self-regulation' is supposed to eliminate any selfish moves or self-interest from these companies' actions. It is a bit like believing in the invisible hands or the peace dividend.

I am certain that all honourable senators received letters, as we did, from people complaining about the petrol companies and outlining the lack of options that tie them up. If the Industry Commission had any integrity, it would have made recommendations as to how the existing laws could be made stronger or made to work better, or it would have made other laws that could be drafted. Asking for self-regulation is asking for the sharks to go on a diet. Please!

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Woodley's concern about the price of petrol and diesel in remote areas of Australia. He has quite correctly pointed out the difference between prices in Brisbane and in those areas that he mentioned. The situation is similar in Western Australia, where there is a vast difference between the prices in outlying areas and those in Perth.

PARA.TAB: However, I would like to point out to the electors of Australia—and especially those people in remote areas who may be listening to this broadcast—that the last policy that the Australian Democrats had on this subject was to raise the price of fuel by 18c a litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell the whole story, Senator Panizza.

—It may be that the Democrats have done away with that policy, but it is still on the record as being their last policy. I admired Senator Woodley for pointing out the difference between the cost of living in the city and that in remote areas and also for saying that transport was not the only factor in this. Much of the difference does relate to transport, but not all. I agree with him on that. But I believe that if the cost of living in the city and in the country is to be brought more into line, we should start by bringing down the price of fuel. The government forever uses the price of fuel as a milking machine to put more into its coffers for its programs.

PARA.TAB: I agree that something should be done to bring the situation back into kilter but, unfortunately, Senator Woodley's good thoughts on this matter were spoilt by the fact that the Democrats' policy—and I have not read anywhere that they have withdrawn it—is to raise the price of fuel by 18c a litre throughout Australia. That would put up the costs in the city and, of course, the costs in the country would be magnified a thousand times. I suggest to Senator Woodley that before he jumps up and tries to lead people in the remote areas—and I know the Democrats are trying to do this; in South Australia and New South Wales, they are trying to take over from the National Party—his party should look at its policy in relation to fuel and adjust it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industry Commission report on petroleum products. To continue with the point that Senator Panizza was making, anyone listening to the senators from the Australian Democrats or the Greens and who wants to blame the cost of fuel in rural or metropolitan Australia on some international conspiracy by oil companies should be reminded that it was those same senators who voted for an increase in the price of fuel when this government broke its promise shortly after the last federal election and, from 1 August, the Australian people had to pay an extra cent per litre.

PARA.TAB: But not only did those senators vote to increase the cost of fuel; they also voted to ensure that the government was given a pat on the back for breaking a promise that it made to the Australian people before the last election. Mr Keating promised no new taxes; he promised tax cuts. Yet these people voted to increase taxes, particularly taxes on petrol.

I urge the people of Australia to understand that more than half of what they pay at the fuel bowser, more than half of what they pay for a litre of petrol, goes into the coffers of state and federal governments. I remind them that the Democrats and Greens joined together to vote for those fuel taxes and, given the opportunity, would vote for a further increase. Let us not hear that the cost of fuel is the fault of some nasty large international oil company. It is the fault of those senators who voted for Mr Keating's massive increases in fuel taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to join my colleagues, in particular Senator Boswell, in doubting, if not indeed rejecting, many of the Industry Commission's recommendations.

PARA.TAB: I have a file two feet thick, in the old measurements, on this issue, which really is an ongoing concern for country people. This report does not tackle that. It does not tackle the fundamental question in relation to petrol pricing.

I concede the point that the government's tax upon petrol, the excise tax, has been an almighty burden upon the retailers and, indeed, the users—the businesses and the households of Australia. It is being used as no more than a revenue raiser and less and less each year is going back into the roads.

That issue aside, the Industry Commission report has not tackled the fundamental issue that concerns at least country people—why is there a difference in price? Five major oil companies have been accused of getting together on a daily basis to set the wholesale price. That allegation is made against the oil companies. When that allegation is put to them, of course they reject it. They give the same tired old argument that the difference is simply no more than transport costs.

I have heard the argument that the difference between the country and the city prices is transport costs. On investigation, that is absolute rubbish. In my own state of Victoria, I have charted each drop-off point, each town, to which petrol supplies go. The Prices Surveillance Authority has published the cost of transporting the petrol and that cost is never more than 2c to 3c per litre. That does not make up for the 13c to 20c difference.

I have produced those charts to the petrol companies. There has been no response. I would have thought that the Industry Commission report would have tackled that very important and serious issue. If that is no longer an argument, why is there a difference between the prices? We are unable to be given a explanation in respect of this fundamental difference. Are the prices being manipulated? TALK.START.PARA: —Ninety-three per cent of New South Wales is now engulfed by the worst drought since white settlement. I know that many areas of Australia are afflicted by this natural disaster, but tonight I would like to focus for a couple of minutes on the Upper Hunter region of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The Scone Rural Lands Protection Board area has been drought declared now for 23 of the last 42 months. The drought started in Scone when it was drought declared for nine months in a row in 1991. The area was drought declared for 16 months in 1991-92. The Merriwa and Mudgee rural lands protection boards have been similarly affected. The New South Wales Department of Agriculture estimates that the Upper Hunter will have to destock approximately 150,000 cattle within the next two months if rain does not come very shortly. Many cattle will have to be shot because they are not saleable, and 15,000 are expected to die of starvation before then. Sixty percent of what is going through the abattoirs across the eastern states at the moment are females, so one can understand the effect that is having on the national gene pool, a gene pool that has been built up for generations and belongs not only to farmers but to each and every Australian.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, has two concerns over a drought fodder subsidy which was proposed by the coalition's response to the drought. He says that it will highly inflate grain prices and that the 1982-83 experience was an example of considerable rorting of the system. Both those allegations really hold no water. Government research shows that grain prices rose only 23 per cent during the 1982-83 drought, and much of that was due to the inflationary impact of the drought anyway. People who are in the market and buying grain at the moment would know that wheat prices have increased nearly 100 per cent in the past six weeks from $165 a tonne to about $230 a tonne today, and that maize, one of the best feeds for sheep, has increased in the past two weeks, if one can get it, from $230 a tonne to around about $300 a tonne on farm. With regard to any talk of rorting of the system, I am not aware of any farmer who was convicted of any such action in the 1982-83 drought.

Scone, Merriwa and Mudgee have now been excluded from the original list of exceptional drought areas after hopes were raised during the much vaunted satellite link-up with the Department of Social Security which the minister had proposed as a way of explaining the government's drought package to interested people.

TALK.START.PARA: —They missed by one month.

—Some of the areas have been in drought much longer than that, as Senator Baume points out. Andrew Badgery, the rural counsellor in the area, has spoken at four drought meetings with up to 100 people at each meeting telling them that they fitted the criteria for assistance. Of the 150 applications made for drought family payment through the New South Wales Rural Assistance Authority, half came from the drought affected area in the Upper Hunter region.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins's office is saying that it was a bureaucratic mistake to put Scone, Merriwa and Mudgee on the television list, or maybe the Department of Primary Industries and Energy realised that the Upper Hunter was harder hit than the minister thought. The rural counsellor has estimated that it was going to cost $5 million to $6 million each for Scone, Merriwa and Mudgee rural lands protection boards. He has estimated that the Upper Hunter would be eligible for about $20 million in family assistance.

Many farms in the Upper Hunter have been severely affected by drought for periods well in excess of 23 months out of the last 42. Individual properties can have had no rain for six months and not be drought declared because at least half of the rural lands protection board is not drought-declared. After much media fanfare surrounding the Prime Minister's drought tour, it is now revealed how inadequate this much heralded response is, although I do applaud the main thrust of what the government is trying to do. It is better late than never.

How can the government say to neighbouring farmers that one is in an exceptional drought circumstance, eligible for assistance, and the other is not? How can the government say to a farmer who cannot put food on his table, has borrowed tens of thousands of dollars to keep his stock alive—stock that has had to be shot or sold anyway—that 23 months of drought declaration is not long enough for him to have suffered?

The drought in the Upper Hunter is so severe that it is threatening the viability of even the best farmers in the region. Farmers have given up their lifestyles, their health and their children's education to minimise debt and maintain their herds at all costs. It would give farmers some hope if the guidelines for the drought package were relaxed slightly. I ask the government to assess each rural lands protection board individually and relax the rigid eligibility criteria. What is to be done for those farmers who miss out on assistance because they do not fall within a geographical area defined by the government?

How we assist these farmers is a matter of identification. It is the government's problem, but those farmers must be identified. As has already been pointed out, 96 per cent of Australian farmers will receive nothing from the government's package and are battling on against the problems of the drought; 100 per cent of small businesses, many of them in the Upper Hunter, will receive nothing. The minister must relax criteria to include all who are suffering severe drought. Combined with high interest rates, low commodity prices, high costs and an unsympathetic government that has done virtually nothing to allow farmers to prepare for severe drought, the drought will cost all Australians dearly.

The continuation of the present circumstances will cause great anxiety and hurt to farming families and rural communities. It will cause great anxiety to the rest of Australia because we will see rising food prices, which we have actually seen already, of at least five per cent, and a flow-on to the CPI of around two per cent, so it will be very inflationary.

Already we have seen the second worst current account in the September quarter, which will only be exacerbated as the drought continues, and that certainly has not started to flow into the current account yet. We have seen higher government borrowings as the deficit blows out, which will mean higher interest rates, and we have the highest real interest rates of the OECD. This drought is impacting on the very fabric of Australia. I wish this government were more sympathetic and more understanding of the drought's impact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in question time, when I asked Senator Cook representing the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to explain whether Australians should do what the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer say is in Australia's best interest—that is, not join in the boom in real estate investment—or whether they should do the opposite and follow the lead of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), I got as usual the spray of personal abuse that is the answer to every matter I ever raise of any substance in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we recognise that there is a point of principle involved that is far more important, and that is that when a Prime Minister significantly increases his exposure to the risk of debt—apparently in this case of the Prime Minister purchasing a $2.2 million mansion in Woollahra, well above the $1 million mark—after he is elected, there is clear merit in his revealing such a change to the public.

Under existing cabinet rules all ministers are required to reveal such changes to their Prime Minister, although this did not apply to Mr Keating. When Mr Keating was Treasurer in May 1991 he failed to tell his Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the details of his $430,000 purchase of a half interest in a piggery group. But breaking the rules is nothing new to Mr Keating: he has made it an art form.

Prime Ministers who otherwise would have to report only to themselves when they made such significant changes in their financial arrangements should instead—it seems to me as a matter of principle—either reveal the details of these changes to the Australian people or else refrain from major commercial undertakings while they are Prime Minister of Australia.

The proprieties that should be observed in such a situation obviously mean nothing to this Prime Minister, who now clearly has a very significant vested interest in government policy affecting both the inflation rate and interest rates; a vested interest he did not have when he came before the Australian people and asked to be elected as their Prime Minister.

This is a significant matter of principle. The Prime Minister has to report to nobody but himself when he changes the enormous exposure that he now has to debt; whereas ministers of the Crown, under the very rules in recognition of the potential for conflict of interest, have to report to the Prime Minister—unless, of course, the Prime Minister happens to be Bob Hawke at the time and the minister involved happens to be Paul Keating, who does not talk to Mr Hawke.

This matter of principle is obviously too difficult for this government to understand. I suppose one should note that the sort of criticism that I have been getting for raising this issue, and the mumbling and rumbling around the gallery by the Prime Minister's henchmen from aNiMaLS to attack me once again is based on one simple proposition. The only defence that the government had was to quote an editorial in the Daily Telegraph Mirror today. It called what I was doing `the politics of envy'. That kind of hypocrisy in that editorial and in the Labor Party's whingeing today about my daring to criticise the Prime Minister is fascinating.

Let us recognise who set the rules. Who raised the class war problem in Australia? Who accused John Hewson and John Howard of being traitors to their class for doing what? For joining the Liberal party! That was their sin. Of course, it was Paul Keating, the great class warrior, who raised this kind of class war nonsense in this place. He set the rules. Who attacked Alexander Downer as the son of the squattocracy? Paul Keating—the class warrior.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable—the very honourable—Paul Keating: the `honourable' class warrior. This disgraceful behaviour goes back for years. He even attacked Malcolm Fraser on the same grounds. He said, `How dare Malcolm Fraser call Nareen home' when he happened to be living in the Lodge at the time. I suppose we could say, `How could Paul Keating call Woollahra home, or his eastern suburbs place at Elizabeth Bay home, when he lives in the Lodge?' The fact is that the politics of envy is the rule that Paul Keating set.

—Mr Paul Keating set. He set those rules and yet he whinges—the appropriate expression would be `like a stuck pig'—if anyone applies the same rules to him. We have a situation where the `politics of envy' is really his expression of the politics of double standards. That is why I intend to continue to pursue this matter. Apart from anything else, it is fascinating to see that the Prime Minister has bought into this mansion at exactly the same time as the Reserve Bank is saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . housing was likely to prove a poor investment at the moment because the current housing investment boom was running far above sustainable levels.

It seems on the face of it that, if the Reserve Bank is right, Mr Paul Keating, the Prime Minister, is about to embark on another of his spectacular investments, like the piggery. While he was a half-owner of the piggery, it lost millions of dollars—and $4.5 million was written off by the Commonwealth Bank as a bad debt. This was while Mr Keating was the half-owner. That was a spectacular failed investment which he claims he has disposed of—without giving us any details.

PARA.TAB: It would seem to me that maybe the Prime Minister has some special sort of protection from failure in this investment, just as he had protection in the last one; because while the Commonwealth Bank lost $4.5 million and the companies lost millions—and five of them ended up technically insolvent with their liabilities exceeding their assets—it appears that Mr Paul Keating could get out of that scot-free. We do not know, of course, because he will not tell us, on what terms he disposed of his interest.

If the value of his investment were to reflect the performance of his companies, that $430,000 would have disappeared. TALK.START.PARA: —It was my melancholy duty nearly 12 months ago to attend the funeral service at RAAF Base Amberley of an F111 crew who had been killed a few days earlier. Today, a very brief statement—a two-page summary—of the investigations into the accident which involved this No. 1 Squadron aircraft was tabled in the Senate. This brief document is the only reference I have to the events as they occurred.

PARA.TAB: The nature of military training, as you would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, is such that it can never be risk free. But it can be conducted safely—and it must be conducted safely. The nature of the exercises that the services are involved in is such that, when they are performed, a very high degree of skill is required. That skill comes from repeated training and great familiarity with the tasks they have to do.

The task that was required of this aircraft this night was to do a number of simulated bombing attacks. It involved the use of the terrain-following radar which the F111 has. The aircraft is flown, in this case at night, probably in bad weather—I do not know about that, but there is a reference to IMC conditions in the latter part of the report—at a height of between 250 and 400 feet, just subsonically.

I have flown in, and I have flown, F111s in that role on this route to the Guyra meatworks. At best, it is a very exhilarating ride for an airman, but it is an exercise that admits of no room for any inaccuracies in the procedure. It confers a very important military capability on Australia to have this terrain-following role in the aircraft of the strike reconnaissance group. It is a role possessed by only two other countries in the Western world: Britain with the RAF and its Tornado aircraft, and the Americans with their F111s.

It is an important capability because the aircraft is moving very fast at a very low level. It is below radar detection levels and it is safe from ground-based missile attack unless it actually flies over the top of a missile site. It is also safe from air intercepts, because the geometry of an intercept of an F111 at 200 feet is extraordinarily difficult. The aircraft is also safe from missile attack from interceptor aircraft because of the possibility of false targets from the ground. The Royal Australian Air Force used to boast—and I do not know whether it is still true—that it was the only air force using a terrain-following capability which trained at night and in bad weather.

It appears from the accident report that what happened that night is that the aircraft flew to the weapons release point at the meatworks at Guyra on the northern end of the New England Tableland. At weapons release point, the procedure is for the aircraft to be rotated with a 3G pull-up to climb, and then it rolls out onto a heading to depart the target area. The allegation in the report is that the pilot failed to release the automatic coupling between the autopilot and the terrain-following radar so that, when he initiated his pull-up, he experienced higher than normal stick forces and the aeroplane did not rotate to the degree it should have. When it reached a pitch angle of between 20 and 25 degrees nose up, the terrain-following radar broke lock and an automatic safety procedure came in which initiated a vertical climb—again a 3G rotation—to clear the aircraft from the ground in case of systems failure in the terrain-following mode.

He then rolled into the approved turn and exceeded the normal bank angle of 110 degrees, which is past the vertical, and presumably went to 140 or 150 degrees. He then reversed the bank to 80 to 90 degrees and sought the heading to depart the target area. In so doing, the aircraft was flown into the ground at very high speed. Both crew members were killed and the aircraft was totally destroyed.

Let no-one be under any misunderstanding about the difficulty of the circumstance, technically, that the pilot was in. It was a very fast aeroplane going just subsonically. It was very close to the ground. It may have been in bad weather—and it was night. There would have been no visual reference for the pilot to orient himself. He was faced with an abnormal set of procedures. Understandably, he would have been trying to work out just what was wrong—and probably not paying the high degree of attention that he should have been paying to the attitude of the aircraft in space. That is how the accident happened. I want to speak about the conclusions in the report. Paragraph 7 states:
Factors that may have contributed to the accident were:

SPEECH.PARA: a. The pilot had not practised this particular kind of attack at night for the preceding five months.

b.The pilot may have been distracted when he possibly realised that he had omitted to disengage the Auto TF system on pull-up initiation during the attack, or by some other unknown factor such as an aircraft component or system failure.
c.The pilot may have suffered from channelised attention due to task saturation—
that is, seeking the heading to depart the target area—

d.Confusion over the unexpected behaviour of the aircraft may have caused him to focus on what was going wrong, to the detriment of situational awareness and the primary task of controlling the aircraft safely.

I find it absolutely astonishing that a pilot should be required to perform a task of that complexity and that danger and not have had any training or practice in it for five months. There would not be a more difficult role for the Australian Strike Reconnaissance Group to fly than that low level, terrain-following attack mission. The question must be asked as to why those five months had elapsed. Was it an administrative oversight within the squadron itself, or was it due to a shortage of funds to the defence department?

PARA.TAB: In the absence of any evidence to the contrary, my assumption is that this is part of the price we pay for the continual cuts we have seen in the defence budget. It is not possible without continual training to fly safely and with the degree of precision required in the roles that we demand of our strike reconnaissance pilots or of our fighter pilots. They are like concert pianists: they have to be at it all the time.

I have been flying for 30 years. I think anyone who has learnt to fly properly can always fly safely. But it is a totally different matter flying to the limits of the flight envelope of a military aircraft in very difficult circumstances. Those pilots have to be at it all the time. I believe that the reductions that we have seen progressively year by year in the number of hours that our fighter pilots and strike reconnaissance pilots fly have passed what is a safe level. We cannot ask people to perform these roles unless they are constantly at it.

Another contributing factor is that it may well have been the state of the simulator at Amberley. It is some years since I have flown that simulator, but it was a real antique when I flew it. I know from estimates committee hearings I have attended that provision has been made in the estimates for the upgrading of that simulator. Whether that has taken place and to what degree it has been or will be upgraded, I do not know.

I come back to the point that I started with in this speech: military training is essentially dangerous. It is dangerous for the people involved. It demands a high level of skill. It can be conducted safely, and it must be conducted safely. We cannot expect strike reconnaissance pilots and fighter pilots to fly to the limits that we want them to fly unless we are supporting them with adequate money to give them adequate training. That includes both the personnel and facilities to train them and the opportunities to fly.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the adjournment debate I want to make a couple of brief comments. The last two speeches on the adjournment have been, in my view, chalk and cheese. Senator Michael Baume, as usual, used the adjournment debate, which he is fully entitled to do, to make strong personal attacks on the integrity of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). We on this side of the chamber know that that is nothing unusual for Senator Baume. He is absolutely obsessed with the Prime Minister. I suspect he cannot put up with the idea that the Prime Minister has been politically successful in leading this country or in being in a major position over the last 11 1/2 years. Nevertheless, Senator Baume is entitled to express his views in the adjournment debate, but I do not think he has any credibility in so doing.

PARA.TAB: I want to contrast Senator Baume's remarks with the remarks of Senator MacGibbon, who raised an issue of some technical complexity for us laymen and women in the Senate about a very tragic accident in the air force where two air force officers lost their lives in a training exercise, as Senator MacGibbon explained. He obviously studied the report, and he commented on it here today in the adjournment debate. I do not know whether I can accept all the assertions that Senator MacGibbon has made, because I am a layman. I am not the Minister for Defence. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) may wish to take exception to some of the remarks that Senator MacGibbon made about the reduction in training time, the lack of resources and so on.

Whether or not I agree with Senator MacGibbon, I respect the way he raised the issue as a legitimate issue to be dealt with, explaining technically for us laymen and women a very complex issue. I think that is the adjournment debate at its best. I think Senator Baume's contribution was the adjournment debate at its worst.

I imagine that Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence, may choose to respond to some of the remarks Senator MacGibbon has made. Senator MacGibbon and I have previously served together on the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and his interest in defence, particularly air force matters, is well known. Being a 30-year flier, as he announced, gives him some advantage.

The issues he raises in making explanations from his perspective is a correct use of the adjournment debate, even if some of us may disagree with him. I cannot disagree or agree with him because the technicalities of the matter are rather complex. I just make the comment that I think we should acknowledge a constructive contribution, even if we disagree with it, compared with the destructive contribution by Senator Baume.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 July 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are Telecom's current arrangements for bond payments on standard telephone service, and how does Telecom decide who should be on a bond.
(2) How many bond-holders does Telecom currently service.
(3) What payment options does Telecom provide for low-income customers.
(4) How much of Telecom's total revenue from the standard phone service was written off as bad debt in the past 3 financial years for which figures are available.

(5) What procedures does Telecom have in place to prevent defaulters from obtaining new services, in particular, what information or identification does it require when new accounts are opened, and how is that information used.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Telecom has advised that its current arrangements for bond payments on standard telephone services are that a security bond will only be required when appropriate credit management assessments indicate that other conditions (such as restrictions on access to IDD) would not adequately protect Telecom's revenue. It is an option of last resort.

Telecom's requirement for a security bond for existing customers is based on their previous credit history with Telecom. New customers who have not had a telephone service in the last six months are assessed on the basis of an objective credit assessment, including any credit history for telephone services that they may have had in the past. It is not Telecom's intention to use security bonds to exclude low income earners and/or disadvantaged sectors of the community from obtaining a telephone service.
(2) Telecom has advised that it regards this information as commercial-in-confidence.

(3) Telecom has advised that it provides a number of payment options for low income customers. These include Telecom's Payment Card, a plastic card that is magnetically encoded with the customer's number that enables individual payments of $10 and above to be made to the account at any time. Other options are shorter billing periods such as monthly accounts that allow for more manageable bills and, if required by the customer, call control facilities including restricted access to STD and IDD.

(4) Telecom has advised that whilst figures for write-offs for bad debts associated with the standard telephone service are not available, Total Bad Debts for the Commercial and Consumer Division, which would principally comprise bad debts associated with telephone services are as follows:
In 1991/92, Telecom's organisational structure was significantly different and therefore comparable figures are not available.

(5) Telecom has advised that it conducts an internal credit risk assessment on all customers ordering a telephone service and keeps that assessment up to date based on the customer's dealings with Telecom. However, Telecom's objective is to provide standard telephone services wherever possible to all Australians, but at the same time it must have regard to revenue protection.

Information sought from potential customers varies with the nature of service sought, but currently includes name, address and telephone details, with additional identification being required in individual cases. Procedures associated with the credit assessment of customers are currently under review.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 8 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that: (a) the marine antifoulant tributyl-tin (TBT) has serious toxin and mutagenic effects on marine organisms; and (b) high levels of contamination in marine organisms, sometimes over 20 nanograms per gram in muscle flesh, have been routinely detected in Western Australian ports such as Cockburn Sound, including HMAS Stirling.
(2) Have any Australian State authorities moved to phase-out the use of TBTs on home-ported vessels, and are there any controls on the anti-foulants coating international shipping.
(3) Is the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency coordinating a national approach to the use of TBTs and other anti-foulants.
(4) What is the extent of the use of TBTs by the Australian Navy.
(5) What measures is the Federal Government taking to support the development of environmentally safe anti-fouling.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Yes; (b) Yes.

(2) Most Australian States have taken action to restrict the use of TBT anti-fouling paints to vessels more than 25 metres long, in accordance with interim measures recommended by the Marine Environment Protection Committee of the International Maritime Organisation in November 1990. There are no controls on the anti-foulants coating international shipping.

(3) Activities have been coordinated by the Maritime Accidents and Pollution Task Force, which was convened by an officer in my Department. The Task Force reported to the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) in December 1993. It is expected that the report will be published later this year.

(4) TBTs are used by the Australian Navy on vessels over 40 metres, and mine hunter inshores and survey motor launches. Leaching rates must meet the standard of 5 micrograms per square centimetre per day recommended by ANZECC in March 1990.

(5) The Australian Navy has an active research and development program studying the properties, performance and reliability of a wide range of anti-foulants, with 45 different systems currently under test.
